This is the Book about which there is no doubt, a guidance for those conscious of Allah -
Who believe in the unseen, establish prayer, and spend out of what We have provided for them,
And who believe in what has been revealed to you, [O Muhammad], and what was revealed before you, and of the Hereafter they are certain [in faith].
Those are upon [right] guidance from their Lord, and it is those who are the successful.
Indeed, those who disbelieve - it is all the same for them whether you warn them or do not warn them - they will not believe.

a.g: Allah has set a seal upon their hearts and upon their hearing, and over their vision is a veil. And for them is a great punishment.
And of the people are some who say, "We believe in Allah and the Last Day," but they are not believers.
They [think to] deceive Allah and those who believe, but they deceive not except themselves and perceive [it] not.
In their hearts is disease, so Allah has increased their disease; and for them is a painful punishment because they [habitually] used to lie.
And when it is said to them, "Do not cause corruption on the earth," they say, "We are but reformers."
Unquestionably, it is they who are the corrupters, but they perceive [it] not.
And when it is said to them, "Believe as the people have believed," they say, "Should we believe as the foolish have believed?" Unquestionably, it is they who are the foolish, but they know [it] not.
And when they meet those who believe, they say, "We believe"; but when they are alone with their evil ones, they say, "Indeed, we are with you; we were only mockers."
[But] Allah mocks them and prolongs them in their transgression [while] they wander blindly.
Those are the ones who have purchased error [in exchange] for guidance, so their transaction has brought no profit, nor were they guided.

As for the hypocrites, they fled from the battle out of fear of death, so it was said to them: "Indeed, the death from which you flee will meet you." Their preferring survival over martyrdom is exchanging that which is lower for that which is better. So those are the ones who purchased misguidance (al-á¸alÄlah) with guidance (al-hudÄ), so their trade did not profit, and they were not guided (muh'tadÄ«n). As for the sincere ones, then Allah the Exalted purchased from them their souls (anfus) and their wealth in exchange for Paradise for them. When they saw that they left enjoyment of twenty years, for example, or thirty years for enjoyment of eternity, they rejoiced at their sale which they transacted. This is the explanation of what is renounced.

a.g: Their example is that of one who kindled a fire, but when it illuminated what was around him, Allah took away their light and left them in darkness [so] they could not see.
Deaf, dumb and blind - so they will not return [to the right path].

Or [it is] like a rainstorm from the sky within which is darkness, thunder and lightning. They put their fingers in their ears against the thunderclaps in dread of death. But Allah is encompassing of the disbelievers.

The lightning almost snatches away their sight. Every time it lights [the way] for them, they walk therein; but when darkness comes over them, they stand [still]. And if Allah had willed, He could have taken away their hearing and their sight. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent.
O mankind, worship your Lord, who created you and those before you, that you may become righteous -

[He] who made for you the earth a bed [spread out] and the sky a ceiling and sent down from the sky, rain and brought forth thereby fruits as provision for you. So do not attribute to Allah equals while you know [that there is nothing similar to Him].

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 4: Meditation
Then look at the Earth while it is dead, then when water is sent down upon it, it quivers, swells, and greens, and brings forth wonders of vegetation, and from it emerge various kinds of animals. Then look at how He has firmly established the sides of the Earth with the towering, lofty, solid, hard mountains, and how He has deposited waters beneath it, so He gushes forth springs, and He makes rivers flow upon its surface, and He brings forth from the dry stones and from the turbid soil water that is delicate, sweet, pure, and cool, and He makes with it every thing alive, so He brings forth with it varieties of trees and vegetation from grain, grapes, herbs, olives, date palms, pomegranates, and many fruits that cannot be enumerated, differing in shapes, colors, tastes, attributes, and fragrances, some excelling over others in eating, watered with one water and emerging from one land. If you say that their difference is due to the difference in their seeds and origins, then when was there in the seed a date palm encircled with clusters of fresh dates, and when was there in a single grain ears of corn, in each ear one hundred? Then look at the land of the deserts and search its surface and interior, and you will see it as similar soil, then when water is sent down upon it, it quivers, swells, and brings forth from every delightful pair different colors and similar vegetation and other.

And in summary, the Quran from its beginning to its end is an argumentation with the disbelievers, so the foundation of the evidences of the theologians in Oneness (Tawhid) is His saying, the Exalted: 'If there were in them (the heavens and earth) gods other than Allah, they would have been corrupted'; and in Prophethood: 'And if you are in doubt about what We have sent down upon Our servant, then bring a surah like it'; and in the Resurrection: 'Say: He gives them life Who created them the first time' - to other than that of the verses and evidences. And the messengers, prayers of Allah be upon them, have not ceased to argue with the deniers and debate them. He, the Exalted, said: 'And argue with them in the best manner'. So the companions, may Allah be pleased with them, also used to argue with the deniers and debate, but only when needed, and the need for it was little in their time.

Indeed, to this secret [sirr] points what has been narrated: that one of the Prophets passed by a small stone from which much water was flowing, and he was astonished by it. So these, when they thought that they were employed for the sake of the poor and the needy, or exalted Allah, then said: 'We have no share in the poor, and Allah has no share in us or in our wealth, whether we spend or withhold,' they perished just as the boy perished when he thought that the father's purpose in employing him was for the sake of the slaves, and he did not realize that the intended purpose was the establishment of the attribute of knowledge in his self (Nafs) and its confirmation in his heart (Qalb) until that becomes the cause of his happiness in this world. Rather, that was from the father as gentleness toward him in drawing him to what contains his happiness. So this example clarifies for you the misguidance of those who went astray from this path. He is like the cupper who extracts blood from you so that by the exit of the blood, the destructive ailment exits from your inner being (Batin). The Narrations: Some of the predecessors said: The first sin is envy (Hasad) - Iblis envied Adam, peace be upon him, for his rank, so he refused to prostrate to him, and it carried him to envy (Hasad) and disobedience. And it was narrated that 'Awn ibn 'Abdullah entered upon al-Fadl ibn al-Muhallab, who was then over Wasit, and said: I want to advise you with something. He said: And what is it? He said: Beware of arrogance (Kibr), for it is the first sin with which Allah was disobeyed, then he recited: "And [mention] when We said to the angels, 'Prostrate to Adam,' and they prostrated, except for Iblis; he refused and was arrogant and became of the disbelievers." And beware of greed (Hirs), for it expelled Adam from Paradise - Allah, glorified be He, had enabled him in a garden the width of the heavens and the earth, to eat from it except one tree which He forbade him from, but he ate from it, so Allah, exalted be He, expelled him from it, then he recited: "Descend from it" to the end of the verse. And beware of envy (Hasad), for indeed the son of Adam killed his brother when he envied him, then he recited: "And recite to them the story of Adam's two sons in truth," the verses. And when the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, are mentioned, then refrain, and when predestination (Qadar) is mentioned, be silent, and when the stars are mentioned, be silent.

The Eighth Duty: That the teacher should act according to his knowledge, so his action does not belie his speech, because knowledge is perceived through insights (Basa'ir) and action is perceived through sights (Absar), and the people of sights are more numerous. So if action contradicts knowledge, it prevents guidance (Rushd). And whoever partakes of something and tells people not to partake of it, then it is a destroying poison; people mock him and accuse him, and their craving for what they are forbidden increases, so they say: 'If it were not the most pleasant and delightful of things, he would not monopolize it.' And the likeness of the guiding teacher from the guided is like the impression from clay and the shadow from the stick; so how can clay be impressed with what has no impression in it, and when the shadow and the stick are equal, it is crooked. Therefore, it is said in meaning: 'Do not forbid a trait and then come with its like; a great disgrace upon you if you do.' And Allah the Exalted said: 'Do you enjoin righteousness upon people and forget yourselves?' (Al-Baqarah: 44). Therefore, the burden (Wizr) of the scholar in his sins is greater than the burden of the ignorant, for many scholars stumble with his stumble and follow him ('And whoever initiates a bad practice, upon him is its burden and the burden of those who act upon it'). Therefore, said Ali, may Allah be pleased with him: 'My back is broken by two men: a scholar who is wanton and an ignorant who is ascetic.' So the ignorant deceives people with his asceticism (Tanasuk), and the scholar deceives them with his wantonness (Tahattuk). And Allah knows best.

And as for the third condition, which is righteousness (Adalah), some people have considered it and said: 'The corrupt person (Fasiq) may not perform commanding good and forbidding evil (Ihtisab).' And perhaps they argued for this with the reprimand that comes upon one who commands what he does not do, such as His saying, the Exalted: 'Do you command people to righteousness (Al-Birr) and forget yourselves while you recite the Book? Do you not then reason?' And His saying, the Exalted: 'Greatly hateful is it with Allah that you say what you do not do.' And with what was narrated from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: 'I passed by on the night of my Ascension (Isra') a people whose lips were being cut with scissors of fire, so I said: "Who are you?" They said: "We used to command good and not do it, and forbid evil and do it."' The hadith 'I passed by on the night of my Ascension a people whose lips were being cut with scissors of fire' preceded in the Book of Knowledge. And with what was narrated that Allah, the Exalted, revealed to Jesus, peace be upon him: 'Admonish yourself; if you are admonished, then admonish people, otherwise be ashamed before Me.' And perhaps they argued from the path of analogy (Qiyas) that guiding others is a branch of being guided, and likewise, rectifying others is a branch of uprightness (Istiqamah), and reform (Islah) is a purification (Zakat) from the measure of righteousness (Salah). So how can one who is not righteous (Salih) in himself reform others, and when will the shadow be straight if the stick is crooked?

a.g: O Children of Israel, remember My favor that I have bestowed upon you and that I preferred you over the worlds.
And fear a Day when no soul will suffice for another soul at all, nor will intercession be accepted from it, nor will compensation be taken from it, nor will they be aided.

And [recall] when We saved your forefathers from the people of Pharaoh, who afflicted you with the worst torment, slaughtering your [newborn] sons and keeping your females alive. And in that was a great trial from your Lord.
And [recall] when We parted the sea for you and saved you and drowned the people of Pharaoh while you were looking on.
And [recall] when We made an appointment with Moses for forty nights. Then you took [for worship] the calf after him, while you were wrongdoers.
Then We forgave you after that so perhaps you would be grateful.
And [recall] when We gave Moses the Scripture and criterion that perhaps you would be guided.

And [recall] when Moses said to his people, "O my people, indeed you have wronged yourselves by your taking of the calf [for worship]. So repent to your Creator and kill yourselves. That is best for [all of] you in the sight of your Creator." Then He accepted your repentance; indeed, He is the Accepting of repentance, the Merciful.
And [recall] when you said, "O Moses, we will never believe you until we see Allah outright"; so the thunderbolt took you while you were looking on.
Then We revived you after your death that perhaps you would be grateful.

And We shaded you with clouds and sent down to you manna and quails, [saying], "Eat from the good things with which We have provided you." And they wronged Us not - but they were [only] wronging themselves.

Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Eating
And Allah said in describing the good things: 'And We shaded you with clouds and sent down upon you manna and quails (al-Salwa).' The manna is honey, and the quails (al-Salwa) is meat. It is called 'salwa' because one consoles oneself (yata-salla) with it over all other dishes, and nothing else takes its place. Therefore, the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'The master of dishes is meat.' Then He said after mentioning the manna and the quails (al-Salwa): 'Eat from the good things (al-Tayyibat) of what We have provided for you.' So meat and sweetness are from the good things (al-Tayyibat).

a.g: And [recall] when We said, "Enter this city and eat from it wherever you will in [ease and] abundance, and enter the gate bowing humbly and say, 'Relieve us of our burdens.' We will [then] forgive your sins for you, and We will increase the doers of good [in goodness and reward]."

But those who wronged changed [those words] to a statement other than that which had been said to them, so We sent down upon those who wronged a punishment from the sky because they were defiantly disobeying.

And [recall] when Moses prayed for water for his people, so We said, "Strike with your staff the stone." And there gushed forth from it twelve springs, and every people knew its watering place. "Eat and drink from the provision of Allah, and do not commit abuse on the earth, spreading corruption."

And [recall] when you said, "O Moses, we can never endure one [kind of] food. So call upon your Lord to bring forth for us from the earth its green herbs and its cucumbers and its garlic and its lentils and its onions." [Moses] said, "Would you exchange what is better for what is less? Go into [any] settlement and indeed, you will have what you have asked." And they were covered with humiliation and poverty and returned with anger from Allah [upon them]. That was because they [repeatedly] disbelieved in the signs of Allah and killed the prophets without right. That was because they disobeyed and were [habitually] transgressing.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Poverty and Abstinence
As for the hypocrites, they fled from the battle out of fear of death, so it was said to them: "Indeed, the death from which you flee will meet you." Their preference for survival over martyrdom is exchanging that which is lower for that which is better. Those are the ones who purchased misguidance for guidance, so their trade did not profit, and they were not guided. As for the sincere ones, Allah the Exalted purchased from them their souls (Nafs) and their wealth in exchange for Paradise for them. When they saw that they had left enjoyment of twenty years, for example, or thirty years for enjoyment of eternity, they rejoiced at their transaction which they had transacted. This is the explanation of what is renounced.

a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 4: Watchfulness and Self-Examination
So it is concluded for every possessor of determination who believes in Allah and the Last Day that he should not neglect accounting his Soul (Nafs) and constraining it in its movements, stillness, fleeting thoughts, and steps. For every breath of life is a precious jewel with no substitute, through which can be purchased a treasure among treasures whose bliss is endless for all eternity. The contraction of these breaths wasted or diverted to what brings destruction is a tremendous, immense loss that no rational Soul (Nafs) would permit. When the servant wakes and finishes the obligatory dawn prayer, he should empty his Heart (Qalb) for an hour to contract with the Soul (Nafs), just as the merchant, when delivering goods to the working partner, empties the gathering to contract with him. He says to the Soul (Nafs): 'I have no merchandise except life; whenever it perishes, the capital has perished, and despair occurs regarding trade and seeking profit. This new day, Allah has granted me respite in it, postponed my term, and bestowed favor upon me. If He had taken me, I would wish to be returned to the world for a single day to work righteous deeds in it. So consider that you have died and then been returned. Beware, then beware, of wasting this day, for every breath of the breaths is a jewel of no value. And know, O Soul (Nafs), that the day and night are twenty-four hours, and it has come in the report that for the servant, with every day and night, twenty-four treasuries are spread out. He opens one of them for him, and he sees it filled with light from his good deeds that he performed in that hour, so he says: 'Indeed, those who have believed and those who were Jews and the Christians and the Sabians - whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day and does righteous deeds - they will have their reward with their Lord, and no fear will there be concerning them, nor will they grieve.'

a.g: And [recall] when We took your covenant, [O Children of Israel, to abide by the Torah] and We raised over you the mount, [saying], "Take what We have given you with determination and remember what is in it that perhaps you may become righteous."
Then you turned away after that. And if not for the favor of Allah upon you and His mercy, you would have been among the losers.
And you had already known about those who transgressed among you concerning the sabbath, and We said to them, "Be apes, despised."
And We made it a deterrent punishment for those who were present and those who succeeded [them] and a lesson for those who fear Allah.
And [recall] when Moses said to his people, "Indeed, Allah commands you to slaughter a cow." They said, "Do you take us in ridicule?" He said, "I seek refuge in Allah from being among the ignorant."
They said, "Call upon your Lord to make clear to us what it is." [Moses] said, "[Allah] says, 'It is a cow which is neither old nor virgin, but median between that,' so do what you are commanded."
They said, "Call upon your Lord to show us what is her color." He said, "He says, 'It is a yellow cow, bright in color - pleasing to the observers.' "
They said, "Call upon your Lord to make clear to us what it is. Indeed, [all] cows look alike to us. And indeed we, if Allah wills, will be guided."

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Foundations of Belief
The third aspect: its basis is doubt, and its meaning is 'I am truly a believer, if Allah wills (In sha' Allah)', since Allah the Exalted said to a specific people by their individuals: 'Those are the ones who are truly believers' {Quran 8:4}. They divided into two groups, and this returns to doubt in the perfection of faith (Iman), not in its foundation. Every person doubts the perfection of their faith, and that is not disbelief (Kufr). Doubt in the perfection of faith is valid from two perspectives: One, from the aspect that hypocrisy (Nifaq) removes the perfection of faith, and it is hiddenâ€”one cannot ascertain freedom from it. Two, that it is perfected by acts of obedience (Taat), and one does not know their existence in perfection. As for action, Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, the believers are those who have believed in Allah and His Messenger, then have not doubted, and have struggled with their wealth and their souls (Anfus) in the cause of Allahâ€”those are the truthful ones' {Quran 49:15}. And as for perfection, He the Exalted said: 'They said, "Call upon your Lord to make clear to us what it is. Indeed, cows look alike to us, and indeed, if Allah wills (In sha' Allah), we will be guided"' {Quran 2:70}. So His saying 'and indeed, if Allah wills (In sha' Allah), we will be guided' is an exception in guidance, even though they were guided to faith in Allah the Exalted, but they doubted the perfection of guidance, so they made an exception.

So, We said, "Strike the slain man with part of it." Thus does Allah bring the dead to life, and He shows you His signs that you might reason.

Then your hearts became hardened after that, being like stones or even harder. For indeed, there are stones from which rivers burst forth, and there are some of them that split open and water comes out, and there are some of them that fall down for fear of Allah. And Allah is not unaware of what you do.

And he (peace be upon him) said: 'Praise (Al-Hamd) is the garment of the Most Merciful (Ar-Rahman).' And Allah the Exalted revealed to Job (peace be upon him): 'I am pleased with gratitude (Ash-Shukr) as a reward from My friends' in a long discourse. And Allah the Exalted also revealed to him regarding the description of the patient ones that their abode is the abode of peace; when they enter it, He inspires them with gratitude (Ash-Shukr), and it is the best of speech, and through gratitude (Ash-Shukr) I increase them, and by looking at them I increase them more. And when what was revealed about treasures was revealed, Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) said: 'What wealth should we acquire?' He said to him: 'What should we acquire?' He (peace be upon him) said: 'Let one of you acquire a tongue that remembers (Dhakir) or a heart that is grateful (Shaakir).' So he commanded acquiring the grateful heart (Al-Qalb Ash-Shaakir) instead of wealth. And Ibn Mas'ud said: 'Gratitude (Ash-Shukr) is half of faith (Al-Iman).' (Explanation of the limit and reality of gratitude) Know that gratitude (Ash-Shukr) is among the stations (Maqaamaat) of the travelers (As-Saalikeen), and it also consists of knowledge (Ilm), state (Haal), and action (Amal). So knowledge (Ilm) is the foundation, and it begets the state (Haal), and the state (Haal) begets the action (Amal). As for knowledge (Ilm), it is recognizing the blessing (An-Ni'mah) from the Bestower (Al-Mun'im). And the state (Haal) is the heart's (Al-Qalb) being affected by gratitude (Ash-Shukr). And the action (Amal) is affirming that with the tongue and limbs. And the heart (Al-Qalb) of the servant (Al-Abd) is like the stones or harder in hardness (Qaswa), and its hardness (Qaswa) does not depart except through weeping in the state (Haal) of fear (Al-Khawf) and gratitude (Ash-Shukr) together.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
The first example: the delusion (Ghurur) of the disbelievers (Kuffar). Among them are those deluded by the worldly life (Al-Hayat Al-Dunya), and among them are those deluded by Allah's delusion. As for those deluded by the worldly life: they are those who said: 'Cash (Naqd) is better than credit (Nasi'ah), and the world (Al-Dunya) is cash and the Hereafter (Al-Akhirah) is credit, so it is therefore better and must be preferred.' And they said: 'Certainty (Yaqin) is better than doubt (Shakk), and the pleasures of the world are certain and the pleasures of the Hereafter are doubtful, so do not abandon certainty for doubt.' And these are corrupt analogies (Aqisah Fasidah) resembling the analogy of Iblis when he said, 'I am better than him; You created me from fire and created him from clay.' And to these is the reference in His saying, the Exalted: 'Those are the ones who have purchased the worldly life [in exchange] for the Hereafter, so the punishment will not be lightened for them, nor will they be aided.' And the treatment for this delusion is either through affirmation of faith (Tasdiq Al-Iman) or through proof (Burhan). As for affirmation through mere faith, it is to believe Allah, the Exalted, in His saying, 'Whatever you have will end, but what Allah has is lasting,' and in His saying, the Mighty and Majestic, 'And what is with Allah is better,' and His saying, 'And the Hereafter is better and more enduring,' and His saying, 'And the worldly life is not but the enjoyment of delusion,' and His saying, 'So let not the worldly life delude you.' And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) informed groups of disbelievers of this, so they imitated him, believed him, and had faith in him without demanding proof. And among them were those who said: 'I adjure you by Allah, has Allah sent you as a messenger?' He would say, 'Yes,' so they would believe. And this is the faith of the common people, and it exits from delusion, and this is placed in the position of a child believing his father that attending the school is better than attending the playground, even though he does not know the aspect of its being better. And these are those who have purchased the worldly life (al-hayat al-dunya) with the Hereafter (al-akhirah), so their transaction has incurred loss, and it was said to the one who intended to guide them: 'So turn away from whoever turns away from Our Remembrance (Dhikr) and desires nothing but the worldly life. And this condition's sign is despair (al-ya's) and hopelessness (al-qunut) and delusion with hopes, which is the utmost foolishness (al-hamq), as he (the Prophet) said: 'The intelligent one (al-kayyis) is he who holds his Soul (Nafs) accountable and works for what is after death, and the foolish one (al-ahmaq) is he who follows his Soul's (Nafs) desire (hawa) and makes wishes upon Allah.' And this wretched one has become his intellect (aql) weak for his lust (shahwah), so he does not employ his intellect except in deducing subtle stratagems through which he attains the fulfillment of his lust. Indeed, his intellect has become in the hands of his lusts like a Muslim captive in the hands of the disbelievers (kuffar); they enslave him in tending pigs, guarding wines, and carrying them. And his place with Allah the Exalted is the place of one who subdues a Muslim and delivers him to the disbelievers and makes him a captive among them, because by his atrocious offense, he resembles one who enslaved what had the right not to be enslaved and empowered what had the right not to be empowered over it. And indeed, the Muslim deserved to be dominant because of what is in him of knowledge of Allah and the motivator of religion (ba'ith al-din), and indeed, the disbeliever deserved to be dominated over because of what is in him of ignorance of religion and the motivator of the devils (ba'ith al-shayatin).

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Status and Ostentation
Look how the ignorant have turned and fallen on their faces like the falling of the blind, so they turned to seeking perfection of power through status and wealth, which is the perfection that does not remain safe and even if it remains safe, it has no permanence, and they turned away from the perfection of freedom and knowledge which, when attained, is eternal with no cessation. And these are the ones who purchased the worldly life with the Hereafter, so it is no wonder that the punishment is not lightened for them nor are they helped. And they are the ones who did not understand His saying, the Exalted: 'Wealth and children are adornment of the worldly life, and the enduring righteous deeds are better with your Lord for reward and better for hope.' So knowledge and freedom are the enduring righteous deeds that remain as perfection in the soul (Nafs), and wealth and status are what perish in proximity, and it is as Allah, the Exalted, has likened it where He said: 'The likeness of the worldly life is as water which We send down from the sky...' the verse. And indeed, the punishment of the scholar in his disobedience is multiplied because he disobeyed from knowledge. Therefore, Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, the hypocrites will be in the lowest depths of the Fire' (An-Nisa: 145). Because they denied after knowledge. And He the Exalted said in the story of Balaam son of Beor: 'And recite to them the news of him to whom We gave Our signs, but he detached himself from them; so Satan pursued him, and he became of the deviators' (Al-A'raf: 175) until He said: 'So his example is like that of the dog: if you chase him, he pants, or if you leave him, he pants' (Al-A'raf: 176). Likewise is the wicked scholar, for Balaam was given the Book of Allah the Exalted, but he inclined to desires, so he was likened to the dog, meaning whether he was given wisdom or not, he pants toward desires.

a.g: Say, "Whoever is an enemy to Gabriel - it is [none but] he who has brought the Qur'an down upon your heart, [O Muhammad], by permission of Allah, confirming that which was before it and as guidance and good tidings for the believers."
Whoever is an enemy to Allah and His angels and His messengers and Gabriel and Michael - then indeed, Allah is an enemy to the disbelievers.
And We have certainly revealed to you verses [which are] clear proofs, and no one would deny them except the defiantly disobedient.
Is it not [true] that every time they took a covenant a party of them threw it away? But, [in fact], most of them do not believe.

And when a messenger from Allah came to them confirming that which was with them, a party of those who had been given the Scripture threw the Scripture of Allah behind their backs as if they did not know [what it contained].

And they followed [instead] what the devils had recited during the reign of Solomon. It was not Solomon who disbelieved, but the devils disbelieved, teaching people magic and that which was revealed to the two angels at Babylon, Harut and Marut. But the two angels do not teach anyone unless they say, "We are a trial, so do not disbelieve [by practicing magic]." And [yet] they learn from them that by which they cause separation between a man and his wife. But they do not harm anyone through it except by permission of Allah. And the people learn what harms them and does not benefit them. But the Children of Israel certainly knew that whoever purchased the magic would not have in the Hereafter any share. And wretched is that for which they sold themselves, if they only knew.
And if they had believed and feared Allah, then the reward from Allah would have been [far] better, if they only knew.
O you who have believed, say not [to Allah 's Messenger], "Ra'ina" but say, "Unthurna" and listen. And for the disbelievers is a painful punishment.

Neither those who disbelieve from the People of the Scripture nor the polytheists wish that any good should be sent down to you from your Lord. But Allah selects for His mercy whom He wills, and Allah is the possessor of great bounty.
We do not abrogate a verse or cause it to be forgotten except that We bring forth [one] better than it or similar to it. Do you not know that Allah is over all things competent?
Do you not know that to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth and [that] you have not besides Allah any protector or any helper?
Or do you intend to ask your Messenger as Moses was asked before? And whoever exchanges faith for disbelief has certainly strayed from the soundness of the way.

Many of the People of the Scripture wish they could turn you back to disbelief after you have believed, out of envy from themselves [even] after the truth has become clear to them. So pardon and overlook until Allah delivers His command. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent.

And perhaps you say: 'Would that the blessing (Nimah) were removed from the envied one by my envy.' This is the utmost ignorance, for it is a calamity (Bala') you first desire for yourself, since you too are not free from an enemy who envies you. If the blessing (Nimah) were removed by envy, there would remain for you no blessing (Nimah) from Allah the Exalted, nor for anyone among creation, nor even the blessing (Nimah) of faith (Iman), because the disbelievers (Kuffar) envy the believers (Mu'minun) for faith (Iman). Allah the Exalted said: 'And many of the People of the Book wish they could turn you back to disbelief after your faith, out of envy from themselves, after the truth has become clear to them. But pardon and overlook until Allah brings His command. Indeed, Allah is over all things competent.' For what the envier (Hasud) desires does not come to be. Yes, he leads astray with his desire for misguidance (Dhalal) for others; if he desires disbelief (Kufr), he disbelieves. So whoever desires that the blessing (Nimah) be removed from the envied one by envy is as if he wants to strip away the blessing (Nimah) of faith (Iman) by the envy of the disbelievers (Kuffar), and likewise all other blessings (Nimam).

And competition may be called envy (Hasad) and envy (Hasad) may be called competition, and one of the two terms may be placed in the position of the other, and there is no restriction in names after understanding the meanings: and the Prophet ï·º said, "The believer envies (Yagbit) and the hypocrite envies (Yahsud)"[101]. As for the first, it is forbidden in every case, except for a blessing that a wicked person or disbeliever attains, and he uses it to stir up strife (Fitnah) and corrupt relationships (Dhat al-Bayn) and harm the truth, so your dislike of it and your love for its removal does not harm you, for you do not love its removal inasmuch as it is a blessing but inasmuch as it is an instrument of corruption, and if you were secure from his corruption, his blessing would not grieve you. And what indicates the prohibition of envy (Hasad) are the reports we have transmitted and that this dislike is displeasure with the decree (Qada) of Allah in preferring some of His servants over others, and there is no excuse or concession in that, and what sin exceeds your dislike of a Muslim's comfort without you having any harm from it? And to this the Quran alluded by His saying, "If good touches you, it distresses them, and if evil befalls you, they rejoice at it," and this rejoicing is gloating (Shamatah) and envy (Hasad) and gloating (Shamatah) are concomitant. And Allah the Exalted said, "And many of the People of the Book wish they could turn you back to disbelief after your belief, out of envy (Hasad) from themselves." So Allah the Exalted informed that their love for the removal of the blessing of faith is envy (Hasad). And He the Mighty and Majestic said, "They wish you would disbelieve as they have disbelieved, so you would be equal." And Allah the Exalted mentioned the envy (Hasad) of the brothers of Joseph, peace be upon him, and expressed what was in their hearts by His saying, "When they said, 'Joseph and his brother are more beloved to our father than we, while we are a clan. Indeed, our father is in clear error. Kill Joseph or cast him out to [another] land; the countenance of your father will [then] be only for you.'" So when they disliked their father's love for him and it distressed them and they loved its removal from him, they concealed him from him. And He said, "And they will not find within their breasts any need for that which they have been given," meaning their breasts do not constrict with it nor do they grieve, so He praised them for the absence of envy (Hasad). And He said in the context of reproach, "Or do they envy (Yahsudun) people for what Allah has given them of His bounty?" And He said, "Mankind was [of] one religion," up to His saying, "Except those to whom it was given after clear proofs had come to them, out of jealousy (Baghyan) among themselves." It is said in the interpretation: envy (Hasad). And He said, "And they did not become divided until after knowledge had come to them out of jealousy (Baghyan) among themselves." So Allah sent down knowledge to gather them and unite them upon His obedience, and He commanded them to unite through knowledge, but they envied (Tahasadu) and differed when each one of them wanted to be alone with leadership (Riyasah) and acceptance of speech, so some of them refuted others. And He, the Exalted, has said: "Have you not considered the one who argued with Abraham about his Lord..." (2:258) until His saying: "So the disbeliever was confounded," when He, glorified be He, mentioned Abraham's argumentation [ihtijaj] and his disputation [mujadalah] and his silencing of his opponent in the context of praising him. And the Mighty and Majestic has said: "And that was Our argument [hujjatuna] which We gave Abraham against his people" (6:83). And He, the Exalted, has said: "They said, 'O Noah, you have disputed [jadaltana] with us and been frequent in your dispute [jidalana] with us'" (11:32). And He, the Exalted, has said in the story of Pharaoh: "And what is the Lord of the worlds?" (26:23) until His saying: "If you should come with clear proof [shay'in mubin]" (26:31). And in summary, the Qur'an from its beginning to its end is an argumentation [muhajjah] with the disbelievers. The core of the theologians' proofs in [the matter of] Divine Oneness [tawhid] is His saying, the Exalted: "Had there been within them [the heavens and earth] gods besides Allah, they both would have been ruined" (21:22). And in [the matter of] Prophethood [nubuwwah]: "And if you are in doubt about what We have sent down upon Our servant, then produce a surah the like thereof" (2:23). And in [the matter of] the Resurrection [ba'th]: "Say, 'He will give them life who produced them the first time'" (36:79), and other such verses and proofs. And the Messengers, prayers of Allah be upon them, never ceased to argue [yuhajjuna] with the deniers and dispute [yujadilunahum] with them. He, the Exalted, has said: "And argue [jadilhum] with them in a way that is best" (16:125). So the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them, also used to argue [yuhajjuna] with the deniers and dispute [yujadiluna] with them, but only when necessary, and the need for it was little in their time. And the first to establish the invitation of the innovators [mubtadi'a] to the truth through disputation [mujadalah] was 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, when he sent Ibn 'Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, to the Khawarij, and he spoke to them. He said, "What do you find fault with regarding your Imam?" They said, "He fought but did not take captives nor take spoils." He said, "That was in fighting the disbelievers. Tell me, if 'A'isha, may Allah be pleased with her, were to be taken as a captive in the share of one of you, would you deem lawful for her what you deem lawful from your spoils, when she is your mother according to the clear text of the Book?" They said, "No." So two thousand of them returned to obedience through his disputation [mujadalatihi]. And it is narrated that Al-Hasan debated [nadhar] a Qadari, so he retracted from [the belief in] Predestination [qadar]. And 'Ali ibn Abi Talib, may Allah honor his face, debated [nadhar] a man from the Qadariyyah. And 'Abdullah ibn Mas'ud, may Allah be pleased with him, debated [nadhar] Yazid ibn 'Umayrah concerning faith [iman]. 'Abdullah said, "If I said, 'I am a believer [mu'min],' I would be saying, 'I am in Paradise.'" He said to him...

a.g: Yes [on the contrary], whoever submits his face in Islam to Allah while being a doer of good will have his reward with his Lord. And no fear will there be concerning them, nor will they grieve.

The Jews say "The Christians have nothing [true] to stand on," and the Christians say, "The Jews have nothing to stand on," although they [both] recite the Scripture. Thus the polytheists speak the same as their words. But Allah will judge between them on the Day of Resurrection concerning that over which they used to differ.

And who are more unjust than those who prevent the name of Allah from being mentioned in His mosques and strive toward their destruction. It is not for them to enter them except in fear. For them in this world is disgrace, and they will have in the Hereafter a great punishment.
And to Allah belongs the east and the west. So wherever you [might] turn, there is the Face of Allah. Indeed, Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing.
They say, "Allah has taken a son." Exalted is He! Rather, to Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and the earth. All are devoutly obedient to Him,
Originator of the heavens and the earth. When He decrees a matter, He only says to it, "Be," and it is.

Those who do not know say, "Why does Allah not speak to us or there come to us a sign?" Thus spoke those before them like their words. Their hearts resemble each other. We have shown clearly the signs to a people who are certain [in faith].

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Book of Knowledge
The Seventh Duty: That one does not delve into a discipline until one has completed the discipline that precedes it, for the sciences are arranged in a necessary order and some of them are a path to others. The successful one is he who observes that order and gradual progression. Allah the Exalted said: 'Those to whom We have given the Book recite it with its true recitation (haqq tilawatihi)' (Al-Baqarah:121). That is, they do not pass beyond a discipline until they have mastered it in knowledge and action. And let his intention in every science he seeks be to ascend to what is above it. Therefore, one should not judge a science as corrupt due to the occurrence of disagreement among its practitioners, nor due to a single error or a few errors within it, nor due to their contravention of what their knowledge necessitates in action. Thus you see a group who abandoned consideration of the rational sciences and the jurisprudential sciences, making excuses in them that if they had a foundation, their masters would have attained it. The uncovering of this doubt has already passed in the book 'Mi'yar al-'Ilm'. And you see a faction who believe in the invalidity of medicine due to an error they witnessed from a physician, and a faction who believed in the correctness of astrology due to correctness that happened for one, and a faction who believed in its invalidity due to an error that happened for anotherâ€”and all of that is error. Rather, one should know the thing in itself, for not every science can be encompassed by every person. And for that reason, 'Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, said: 'Do not know the truth through men; know the truth and you will know its people.'

The foolish among the people will say, "What has turned them away from their qiblah, which they used to face?" Say, "To Allah belongs the east and the west. He guides whom He wills to a straight path."

And thus we have made you a just community that you will be witnesses over the people and the Messenger will be a witness over you. And We did not make the qiblah which you used to face except that We might make evident who would follow the Messenger from who would turn back on his heels. And indeed, it is difficult except for those whom Allah has guided. And never would Allah have caused you to lose your faith. Indeed Allah is, to the people, Kind and Merciful.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Travel
As for the sufficiency of the direction (al-jiha) when direct observation is impossible, this is indicated by the Book (al-Kitab), the Prophetic Tradition (al-Sunnah), the actions of the Companions (al-Sahaba) - may Allah be pleased with them - and analogical reasoning (al-Qiyas). Know that Allah the Exalted coupled Gratitude (Shukr) with Remembrance (Dhikr) in His Book, even though He said: 'And the Remembrance (Dhikr) of Allah is greater' (Quran 29:45). So He the Exalted said: 'So remember Me; I will remember you. And be grateful to Me and do not deny Me' (Quran 2:152). And He the Exalted said: 'What would Allah do with your punishment if you are grateful and believe?' (Quran 4:147). And He the Exalted said: 'And We will reward the grateful ones' (Quran 3:145). And He the Mighty and Majestic, informing about Satan the accursed: 'I will surely sit in wait for them on Your straight path' (Quran 7:16). It is said it is the path of Gratitude (Shukr), and due to the high rank of Gratitude (Shukr), the accursed one attacked the creation, saying: 'And you will not find most of them grateful' (Quran 7:17). And He the Exalted said: 'And few of My servants are grateful' (Quran 34:13). And Allah the Exalted has affirmed increase with Gratitude (Shukr) without exception, saying: 'If you are grateful, I will surely increase you' (Quran 14:7). And He made exceptions in five things: in enrichment, response, provision, forgiveness, and repentance, saying: 'Then Allah will enrich you from His bounty if He wills' (Quran 9:28), and said: 'He removes what you call to if He wills' (Quran 6:41), and said: 'He provides for whom He wills without account' (Quran 2:212), and said: 'And He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills' (Quran 4:48), and said: 'And Allah turns in forgiveness to whom He wills' (Quran 9:27). And it is a character from the characters of Lordship (Rububiyyah), as He the Exalted said: 'And Allah is Appreciative (Shakur) and Forbearing' (Quran 64:17). And Allah has made Gratitude (Shukr) the key to the speech of the people of Paradise, saying: 'And they will say, "Praise to Allah, who has fulfilled for us His promise"' (Quran 39:74), and said: 'And their last call will be, "Praise to Allah, Lord of the worlds"' (Quran 10:10).

Know that God the Exalted has coupled gratitude [shukr] with remembrance [dhikr] in His Book, even though He said: "And the remembrance of God is greater." Indeed, He the Exalted said: "So remember Me; I will remember you. And be grateful to Me and do not deny Me." And He the Exalted said: "What would God do with your punishment if you are grateful and believe?" And He the Exalted said: "And We will reward the grateful." And He, Mighty and Majestic, said, informing about the accursed Iblis: "I will surely sit in wait for them on Your straight path." It is said it is the path of gratitude [shukr], and due to the loftiness of the rank of gratitude [shukr], the accursed one cast aspersions on creation, saying: "And you will not find most of them grateful [shakirin]." And He the Exalted said: "And few of My servants are grateful [shakur]." And God the Exalted has decreed increase with gratitude [shukr] without exception, for He the Exalted said: "If you are grateful, I will surely increase you." And He made exceptions in five things: in granting sufficiency, in answering, in provision, in forgiveness, and in repentance. For He the Exalted said: "Then God will grant you sufficiency from His bounty, if He wills." And He said: "He removes that for which you supplicate Him, if He wills." And He said: "He provides for whom He wills without account." And He said: "And He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills." And He said: "And God turns in forgiveness to whom He wills." And it is a creation from the attributes of Lordship, for He the Exalted said: "And God is Appreciative [shakur] and Forbearing." And God has made gratitude [shukr] the key speech of the people of Paradise, for He the Exalted said: "And they will say, 'Praise to God, who has fulfilled for us His promise.'" And He said: "And their final call will be, 'Praise to God, Lord of the worlds.'" As for the narrations, the Messenger of God, peace be upon him, said: "The grateful eater is of the same rank as the patient faster." And it is narrated from 'Ata that he said: "I entered upon 'A'ishah, may God be pleased with her, and said, 'Inform us of the most amazing thing you saw from the Messenger of God, peace be upon him.' She wept and said, 'And which of his affairs was not amazing? He came to me one night and entered the bed with me'â€”or she said, 'my blanket'â€”'until his skin touched my skin. Then he said, "O daughter of Abu Bakr, allow me to worship my Lord." I said, "I love your closeness, but I prefer your desire." So I gave him permission. He stood up to a water-skin, performed ablution without using much water, then stood to pray. He wept until his tears flowed onto his chest. Then he bowed and wept. Then he prostrated and wept. Then he raised his head and wept. He continued like that, weeping, until Bilal came to give the call to prayer. a.g: O you who have believed, seek help through patience and prayer. Indeed, Allah is with the patient.
And do not say about those who are killed in the way of Allah, "They are dead." Rather, they are alive, but you perceive [it] not.
And We will surely test you with something of fear and hunger and a loss of wealth and lives and fruits, but give good tidings to the patient,
Who, when disaster strikes them, say, "Indeed we belong to Allah, and indeed to Him we will return."
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Earning a Livelihood
Indeed, the third category: that which does not fall under the scope of choice, neither its beginning nor its end, such as calamities [masha'ib]â€”like the death of loved ones, the loss of wealth, the removal of health through illness, the blindness of the eye, the corruption of limbs, and in sum, all other types of affliction [bala']. So patience [sabr] upon that is from the highest stations of patience. Ibn Abbas, may God be pleased with them both, said: "Patience in the Quran is upon three aspects: patience upon performing the obligations [fara'id] of God, the Exalted, for it are three hundred degrees; and patience in abstaining from the prohibitions [maharim] of God, the Exalted, for it are six hundred degrees; and patience upon the calamity [musiba] at the first shock, for it are nine hundred degrees." And this rank is favored, even though it is from the virtues [fada'il] over what preceded itâ€”and they are from the obligationsâ€”because every believer is capable of patience in abstaining from the prohibitions. As for patience upon the affliction [bala'] of God, the Exalted, none can bear it except the Prophets, for it is the merchandise of the truthful [siddiqin]; indeed, that is severe upon the soul [nafs], and for that reason He, peace be upon him, said: "I ask You for such certainty [yaqin] that by it the calamities of the world [dunya] are made light for me." So this is a patience whose foundation is sound certainty [yaqin]. And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "God, Mighty and Majestic, said: 'When I direct a calamity [musiba] to a servant from My servants in his body, or his wealth, or his child, then he meets that with beautiful patience [sabr jamil], I am ashamed before him on the Day of Resurrection to set up a scale for him or to unfurl a record for him.'" And He, peace be upon him, said: "There is no believing servant afflicted by a calamity [musiba] who says as God, the Exalted, has commanded: 'Indeed we belong to God, and indeed to Him we return,' and 'O God, reward me for my calamity and grant me better than it,' except that God will do that for him."

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Invocations and Supplications
[206] The saying when one hears of someone's death: 'Indeed we belong to Allah and indeed to Him we will return, and indeed to our Lord we are returning. O Allah, record him among the doers of good (al-Muhsinin) and place his record in the highest (Illiyyin), and replace him for his offspring among the later generations (al-Ghabirin). O Allah, do not deprive us of his reward and do not test us after him, and forgive us and him.' It was reported by Ibn al-Sunni in 'The Day and Night' and Ibn Hibban from the hadith of Umm Salamah: 'When a calamity (musibah) befalls one of you, let him say: Indeed we belong to Allah and indeed to Him we will return.' And in Muslim from her hadith: 'O Allah, forgive Abu Salamah and raise his rank among the guided ones (al-Mahdiyyin), and replace him for his offspring among the later generations (al-Ghabirin), and forgive us and him, O Lord of the worlds, and expand for him in his grave and illuminate it for him.'

And Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, used to say: 'How excellent are the two scales and how excellent is the additional load for the patient ones.' He meant by 'the two scales': the prayer and the mercy, and by 'the additional load': the guidance. And 'the additional load' is what is carried above the two scales on the camel. ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Status and Ostentation
Look how the ignorant have turned and fallen on their faces like the falling of the blind, so they turned to seeking perfection of power through status and wealth, which is a perfection that does not remain safe, and if it remains safe, it has no permanence, and they turned away from the perfection of freedom and knowledge which, when attained, is eternal with no cessation. And these are the ones who have purchased the worldly life in exchange for the Hereafter, so indeed no punishment is lightened for them, nor are they given respite. And they are the ones who did not understand His saying, the Exalted: 'Wealth and children are the adornment of the worldly life, but the enduring righteous deeds are better with your Lord for reward and better for hope.' So knowledge and freedom are the enduring righteous deeds which remain as perfection in the soul (Nafs), and wealth and status are what perish in proximity, and it is as Allah, the Exalted, has likened it where He said: 'The example of the worldly life is like water which We send down from the sky...' the verse.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Arrangement of Litanies
And it is recommended to recite the specified verses such as the Throne Verse (Ayat al-Kursi) and the end of Al-Baqarah and others, and His saying, the Exalted: 'And your god is one god; there is no god except Him' until His saying: 'for a people who use reason.' It is said that whoever recites it at sleep, Allah preserves the Quran for him so he does not forget it. And he recites from Surah Al-A'raf this verse: 'Indeed, your Lord is Allah, who created the heavens and earth in six days' until His saying: 'is near to the doers of good.' And the end of Bani Isra'il 'Say, "Call upon Allah"' the two verses, for then a king enters his emblem who is entrusted with his protection, so he seeks forgiveness for him. And he recites the two surahs of seeking refuge (Al-Mu'awwidhatayn) and blows with them into his hands and wipes with them his face and the rest of his body; likewise, it is narrated from the action of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. And let him recite ten from the beginning of Al-Kahf and ten from its end, and these verses are for awakening for the night prayer (Qiyam al-Layl). And Ali, may Allah honor his face, said: 'I do not think that a man with complete intellect sleeps before reciting the two verses from the end of Surah Al-Baqarah.' And let him say twenty-five times: 'Glory be to Allah (Subhan Allah) and praise be to Allah (Alhamdulillah) and there is no god but Allah (La ilaha illa Allah) and Allah is the greatest (Allahu Akbar)' so that the total of these four words becomes four hundred times.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Foundations of Belief
The First Foundation: Knowledge of His Existence, the Most High, and the first of the lights by which illumination is sought and the path of reflection that is followed is what the Quran has guided to, for there is no explanation after the explanation of Allah, the Glorified. And He, the Most High, has said: 'Have We not made the earth a resting place, and the mountains as pegs, and created you in pairs, and made your sleep a repose, and made the night a covering, and made the day for livelihood, and built above you seven firm ones, and made a blazing lamp, and sent down from the rain-clouds pouring water to bring forth thereby grain and vegetation and gardens of dense growth?' And He, the Most High, said: 'Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day and the ships that sail in the sea with that which benefits people, and what Allah has sent down from the sky of water, then He gives life thereby to the earth after its death and disperses therein every moving creature, and the directing of the winds and the clouds subjected between the heaven and the earth are signs for a people who use reason.' And He, the Most High, said: 'Have you not seen how Allah created seven heavens in layers and made the moon therein a light and made the sun a lamp? And Allah has caused you to grow from the earth a growth, then He will return you into it and bring you forth a bringing forth.' And He, the Most High, said: 'Then do you see that which you emit? Is it you who creates it, or are We the Creator?' up to His saying: 'for the grateful.' So it is not hidden from one who possesses the slightest bit of intellect, if he reflects with the least thought upon the content of these verses and turns his gaze upon the wonders of Allah's creation in the earth and the heavens and the marvels of the innate nature (Fitra) of animals and plants, that this amazing affair and precise arrangement cannot do without a Maker who manages it and an Agent who governs and determines it. Rather, the innate nature (Fitra) of the souls (Nufus) almost testifies to being subdued under His subjugation and directed according to His management. And for that reason, Allah, the Most High, said: 'Is there any doubt concerning Allah, Creator of the heavens and the earth?'

A day while they were contemplating (yatafakkarÅ«n), so he said: 'What is with you that you do not speak?' They said: 'We contemplate (natafakkar) in the creation of Allah.' The hadith we narrated in a part of the hadith of Abdullah ibn Salam. And from Ata' he said: 'One day I and Ubaid ibn Umair went to Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, and she spoke to us while there was a curtain between us and her. She said: O Ubaid, what prevents you from visiting us? He said: The saying of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Visit infrequently, you will increase in love.' Ibn Umair said: So inform us of the most amazing thing you saw from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him. He said: So she wept and said: Every matter of his was amazing. He came to me in my night until his skin touched my skin, then he said: Leave me to worship my Lord, the Mighty and Majestic. So he stood up to the water-skin and performed ablution from it, then he stood praying and wept until his beard became wet, then he prostrated until the ground became wet, then he lay on his side until Bilal came to call him to the dawn prayer. He said: O Messenger of Allah, what makes you weep when Allah has forgiven you your past and future sins? He said: Woe to you, O Bilal, and what prevents me from weeping when Allah the Exalted revealed to me in this night: 'Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth and the alternation of the night and the day are signs for those of understanding (Å«lÄ« al-albÄb).' Then he said: Woe to the one who recites it and does not contemplate (yatafakkar) in it.' The hadith of Ata': 'I and Ubaid ibn Umair went to Aisha...' The hadith. Ibn Umair said: 'So inform us of the most amazing thing you saw from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him.' The hadith regarding the revelation of 'Indeed, in the creation of the heavens and the earth...' and he said: 'Woe to the one who recites it and does not contemplate (yatafakkar) in it.' It preceded in patience and gratitude that it is in Sahih Ibn Hibban from the narration of Abdul Malik ibn Abi Sulaiman from Ata'. It was said to Al-Awza'i: What is the ultimate goal of contemplation (tafakkur) in them? He said: To recite them and comprehend them.

Vol 4: Meditation
Then look at the wonders of the atmosphere and what appears in it of clouds, thunders, lightnings, rains, snows, meteors, and thunderboltsâ€”these are wonders between the heaven and the earth. The Quran has pointed to the totality of this in His saying, the Exalted: 'And We did not create the heavens and the earth and what is between them in play.' And this is what is between them. And He pointed to its details in various places where He said, the Exalted: 'And the clouds subjugated between the heaven and the earth,' and where He mentions the thunder, lightning, clouds, and rain. If you have no share of this totality except that you see the rain with your eye and hear the thunder with your ear, then the beast shares with you in this knowledge. So rise from the lowliness of the world of beasts to the world of the highest assembly. For you have opened your eyes and perceived its outward aspect, so close your outward eye and look with your inner insight (Batin) to see the wonders of its inward aspect and the marvels of its secrets. And this is also a door that lengthens thought in it, for there is no hope in exhausting it. So contemplate the dense, dark cloudâ€”how you see it gather in a pure atmosphere with no turbidity in it, and how Allah, the Exalted, creates it when He wills and whenever He wills. And it, with its softness, carries the heavy water and holds it in the atmosphere of the heaven until Allah permits in sending the water and cutting the layers, every drop with the measure that Allah, the Exalted, has willed and in the form that He has desired. So you see the cloud sprinkling water upon the earth and sending it as separate dropsâ€”no drop of them catches another drop, nor does one connect with another. Rather, each one descends in the path that has been delineated for it, not deviating from it, so the later does not precede nor the earlier delay until it strikes the earth drop by drop. If the first and the last were to gather to create from it a drop or to know the number of what descends from it in a single town or village, the calculation of the jinn and mankind would be incapable.

Know that the community (Ummah) is unanimous that love for Allah the Exalted and His Messenger (peace be upon him) is obligatory (Fard), and how can something that does not exist be made obligatory, and how can love be interpreted as obedience when obedience follows love and is its fruit? It is necessary that love comes first, and then after that one obeys whom one loves. And what indicates the affirmation of love for Allah the Exalted is His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: "He loves them and they love Him" and His saying: "And those who believe are stronger in love for Allah." This is evidence for affirming love and affirming variation in it.

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of the World
Indeed, as for what follows: The world [al-dunya] is an enemy to Allah, and an enemy to the allies [awliya'] of Allah, and an enemy to the enemies of Allah. As for its enmity to Allah: It has cut off the path [al-tariq] from the servants of Allah. And for that reason, Allah has not looked upon it since He created it. And as for its enmity to the allies [awliya'] of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic: It adorned itself for them with its adornment, and blinded them with its splendor and freshness, until they drank the bitterness of patience [al-sabr] in severing ties with it. And as for its enmity to the enemies of Allah: It gradually lured them with its guile and its plot, then snatched them with its net, until they placed their trust in it and relied upon it. Then it abandoned them at the time of their greatest need for it. So they reaped from it a regret [hasra] that causes hearts [al-akbad] to be torn apart. Then it deprived them of felicity [al-sa'ada] for all eternity. They are in separation from it, regretful, and from its plots they cry for help, but they are not given succor. Rather, it is said to them: "Be driven into it, and do not speak to Me. Those are the ones who purchased the worldly life [al-hayat al-dunya] with the Hereafter [al-akhira]; so the punishment will not be lightened for them, nor will they be helped."

a.g: Those are the ones who have exchanged guidance for error and forgiveness for punishment. How patient they are in pursuit of the Fire!
That is [deserved by them] because Allah has sent down the Book in truth. And indeed, those who differ over the Book are in extreme dissension.

Righteousness is not that you turn your faces toward the east or the west, but [true] righteousness is [in] one who believes in Allah, the Last Day, the angels, the Book, and the prophets and gives wealth, in spite of love for it, to relatives, orphans, the needy, the traveler, those who ask [for help], and for freeing slaves; [and who] establishes prayer and gives zakah; [those who] fulfill their promise when they promise; and [those who] are patient in poverty and hardship and during battle. Those are the ones who have been true, and it is those who are the righteous.

The second: that it (faith) is perfected by works of obedience (al-Ta'at) and one does not know their existence in perfection. So this is what indicates the connection of the perfection of faith (al-Iman) with works.

Know that patience [sabr] is of two kinds. The first is a bodily kind, such as enduring hardships with the body and remaining steadfast upon them. This is either through action, such as undertaking strenuous works, whether from acts of worship or otherwise, or through endurance, such as patience [sabr] with severe beating, great illness, and terrible wounds. This can be praiseworthy if it conforms to the Sacred Law, but the complete praiseworthy kind is the other kind, which is the patience [sabr] of the soul [nafs] from the desires of one's nature and the demands of caprice [hawa]. Then, this kind, if it is patience [sabr] against the desire of the stomach and the private parts, it is called chastity ['iffa]. If it is in enduring a disliked thing, its names differ among people according to the difference of the disliked thing which patience [sabr] has overcome. If it is in a calamity, it is confined to the name 'patience' [sabr], and its opposite state is called panic [jaza'] and alarm [hala'], which is releasing the caller of caprice [hawa] to give free rein in raising the voice, striking the cheeks, tearing the collars, and other such acts. If it is in enduring wealth, it is called self-restraint [dabt al-nafs], and its opposite state is called arrogance [batr]. If it is in war and fighting, it is called courage [shaja'a], and its opposite is cowardice [jubn]. If it is in suppressing rage and anger, it is called forbearance [hilm], and its opposite is complaint [tadammur]. If it is in an afflicting calamity from the calamities of time, it is called breadth of the chest [sa'at al-sadr], and its opposite is impatience [dajar] and vexation [tabarram] and narrowness of the chest [dayq al-sadr]. If it is in concealing speech, it is called keeping a secret [kitman al-sirr], and its possessor is called secretive [katum]. If it is from the excesses of life, it is called renunciation [zuhd], and its opposite is greed [hirs]. If it is patience [sabr] upon a small portion of shares, it is called contentment [qana'a], and its opposite is avarice [sharah]. Thus, most of the character traits of faith [iman] are included within patience [sabr]. For this reason, when He, peace be upon him, was once asked about faith [iman], he said: "It is patience [sabr]," because its acts are many and most noble, just as He said: "Perform Hajj at 'Arafah." And Allah, the Exalted, has gathered all these divisions and named the whole of it 'patience' [sabr], saying, the Exalted: "And those who are patient [al-sabirin] in poverty [al-ba'sa']" â€“ meaning calamity â€“ "and hardship [al-darra']" â€“ meaning poverty â€“ "and when in battle [hina al-ba's]" â€“ meaning warfare â€“ "It is they who have been true, and it is they who are the righteous [al-muttaqun]." Therefore, these are the divisions of patience [sabr] according to the differences of their objects.

a.g: O you who have believed, prescribed for you is legal retribution for those murdered - the free for the free, the slave for the slave, and the female for the female. But whoever overlooks from his brother anything, then there should be a suitable follow-up and payment to him with good conduct. This is an alleviation from your Lord and a mercy. But whoever transgresses after that will have a painful punishment.
And there is for you in legal retribution [saving of] life, O you [people] of understanding, that you may become righteous.

Prescribed for you when death approaches [any] one of you if he leaves wealth [is that he should make] a bequest for the parents and near relatives according to what is acceptable - a duty upon the righteous.
Then whoever alters the bequest after he has heard it - the sin is only upon those who have altered it. Indeed, Allah is Hearing and Knowing.
But if one fears from the bequeather [some] error or sin and corrects that which is between them, there is no sin upon him. Indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
O you who have believed, decreed upon you is fasting as it was decreed upon those before you that you may become righteous -

[Fasting for] a limited number of days. So whoever among you is ill or on a journey [during them] - then an equal number of days [are to be made up]. And upon those who are able [to fast, but with hardship] - a ransom [as substitute] of feeding a poor person [each day]. And whoever volunteers excess - it is better for him. But to fast is best for you, if you only knew.

The month of Ramadhan [is that] in which was revealed the Qur'an, a guidance for the people and clear proofs of guidance and criterion. So whoever sights [the new moon of] the month, let him fast it; and whoever is ill or on a journey - then an equal number of other days. Allah intends for you ease and does not intend for you hardship and [wants] for you to complete the period and to glorify Allah for that [to] which He has guided you; and perhaps you will be grateful.

a.g: It has been made permissible for you the night preceding fasting to go to your wives [for sexual relations]. They are clothing for you and you are clothing for them. Allah knows that you used to deceive yourselves, so He accepted your repentance and forgave you. So now, have relations with them and seek that which Allah has decreed for you. And eat and drink until the white thread of dawn becomes distinct to you from the black thread [of night]. Then complete the fast until the sunset. And do not have relations with them as long as you are staying for worship in the mosques. These are the limits [set by] Allah, so do not approach them. Thus does Allah make clear His ordinances to the people that they may become righteous.

And do not consume one another's wealth unjustly or send it [in bribery] to the rulers in order that [they might aid] you [to] consume a portion of the wealth of the people in sin, while you know [it is unlawful].

And He (Allah), the Exalted, said: 'And do not consume your properties among yourselves unjustly (Bil-Batil).' And He, the Exalted, said: 'Indeed, those who consume the properties of the orphans unjustly...' the verse. And He, the Exalted, said: 'O you who have believed, fear Allah (Taqwa) and give up what remains [due to you] of interest (Riba), if you should be believers.' Then He said: 'And whoever returns [to dealing in interest] - those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally.' He made the consumer of interest (Riba) at the beginning of the matter announcing war against Allah and at its end exposed to the Fire. And the verses concerning the lawful (Halal) and the unlawful (Haram) are innumerable.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Companionship
And it was narrated that Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) was patrolling in Medina at night when he heard a man's voice in a house singing, so he climbed over the wall to him and found him with a woman and with wine. He said: 'O enemy of Allah, did you think that Allah would conceal you while you are in disobedience to Him?' The man said: 'And you, O Commander of the Faithful, do not hasten. If I have disobeyed Allah in one matter, you have disobeyed Allah in three matters. Allah the Exalted said: "And do not spy" (Quran 49:12), and you have spied. And Allah the Exalted said: "And it is not righteousness (Al-Birr) that you come to the houses from their backs" (Quran 2:189), and you have climbed over the wall to me. And Allah the Exalted said: "Do not enter houses other than your own houses" (Quran 24:27), and you have entered my house without permission and without greeting.' Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) said: 'Do you have any good if I pardon you?' He said: 'Yes, by Allah, O Commander of the Faithful, if you pardon me, I will never return to the like of it ever.' So he pardoned him and left and abandoned him.

Vol 2: Enjoining Good and Forbidding Evil
If it is said: What is the meaning of His saying, the Exalted: 'And do not throw yourselves with your own hands into destruction'? We say: There is no disagreement that a single Muslim may charge into the ranks of the disbelievers and fight even if he knows he will be killed. This might be thought to contradict the requirement of the verse, but it is not so. Indeed, Ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: 'That is not the destruction; rather, it is abandoning spending in obedience to Allah, the Exaltedâ€”meaning, whoever does not do that has destroyed himself.' And Al-Bara' ibn 'Azib said: 'The destruction is that one commits a sin then says: I will not be forgiven.' And Abu 'Ubaydah said: 'It is that one sins then does not do any good afterward until he perishes.' And if it is permissible to fight the disbelievers until one is killed, then it is also permissible for him in enjoining good and forbidding evil (al-Hisbah). But if he knows there is no harm from his charge against the disbelievers, like a blind man throwing himself upon the ranks or a disabled person, then that is forbidden and falls under the generality of the verse of destruction. And it is only permissible for him to advance if he knows he will fight until he is killed or knows that he will break the hearts (Qulub) of the disbelievers by their witnessing his bravery and their belief in the rest of the Muslims' lack of concern and their love for martyrdom in the path of Allah, so their strength is broken by that. Likewise, it is permissible for the enforcer of good (al-Muhtasib), indeed recommended for him, to expose himself to beating and to killing if his enforcement has an effect in lifting the evil or in breaking the prestige of the corrupt person or in strengthening the hearts (Qulub) of the people of the religion.

The third is the Enjoyment (Tamattu') which is that one passes the designated point (Miqat) in the state of consecration (Ihram) for the 'Umrah and becomes free from restrictions (Tahallul) in Makkah and enjoys the prohibited things until the time of Hajj, then enters the state of consecration (Ihram) for Hajj. One is not considered a performer of Enjoyment (Tamattu') except with five conditions: First, that he not be from the residents of the Sacred Mosque (Masjid al-Haram), and its resident is one who is from it at a distance where prayer is not shortened. Second, that he perform the 'Umrah before the Hajj. Third, that his 'Umrah be in the months of Hajj. Fourth, that he not return to the designated point (Miqat) of Hajj nor to a distance equivalent to it for the consecration (Ihram) of Hajj. Fifth, that his Hajj and 'Umrah be for one person. If these descriptions are found, he is a performer of Enjoyment (Tamattu') and a sheep as sacrifice (Dam) is obligatory upon him. If he does not find [it], then fasting three days during Hajj before the Day of Sacrifice (Yawm al-Nahr), separately or consecutively, and seven when he returns to the homeland. And if he does not fast the three until he returns to the homeland, he fasts the ten consecutively or separately. The substitute (Badal) for the sacrifice (Dam) of the Combined (Qiran) and the Enjoyment (Tamattu') is the same, and the best is the Single (Ifrad), then the Enjoyment (Tamattu'), then the Combined (Qiran).

Perhaps you say: "These reports indicate that tribulation [bala'] is better in this world [dunya] than blessings [ni'am]. So, is it for us to ask Allah for tribulation?" I say: There is no basis for that, because it is narrated from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that he would seek refuge in his supplication from the tribulation of this world and the tribulation of the Hereafter [akhira]. And he, and the Prophets, peace be upon them, would say: "Our Lord, grant us good in this world and good in the Hereafter." And they would seek refuge from the gloating of enemies and other things. And 'Ali, may Allah honor his face, said: "O Allah, I ask You for patience [sabr]." So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "You have asked for tribulation, so ask Him for well-being ['afiya]." And it is narrated from al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, that he said: "Ask Allah for well-being, for no one has been given anything better than well-being except certainty [yaqin]." And he indicated by 'certainty' the well-being of the heart [qalb] from the sickness of ignorance [jahl] and doubt [shakk]. So the well-being of the heart is higher than the well-being of the body. And al-Hasan, may Allah have mercy on him, said: "The good in which there is no evil is well-being with gratitude [shukr], for how many are those upon whom blessings are bestowed who are not grateful." And Mutarrif ibn 'Abdullah said: "That I be granted well-being and be grateful is more beloved to me than that I be afflicted and be patient." And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said in his supplication: "And Your well-being is more beloved to me." This is clearer than to need proof and evidence for it. And this is because tribulation becomes a blessing [ni'ma] by two considerations: One of them is in relation to what is greater than it, either in this world or in religion [din]. And the other is in relation to what is hoped for of reward [thawab]. Therefore, we should ask Allah for the perfection of blessing in this world and the removal of what is beyond it of tribulation. And we ask Him for reward in the Hereafter for gratitude [shukr] for His blessing, for He is capable of granting for gratitude what He does not grant for patience.
