ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Status and Ostentation
"The First": Ostentation (Riya) with the foundation of faith (Iman), and this is the most severe of the gates of ostentation, and its practitioner is eternally in the Fire (Nar), and he is the one who manifests the two testimonies (Shahadatayn) while his inner self (Batin) is filled with denial (Takdhib) but he shows off with the outward appearance (Zahir) of Islam, and he is the one whom Allah the Exalted mentioned in His Book in various places such as His saying, exalted is He: "When the hypocrites (Munafiqun) come to you, they say: 'We bear witness that you are indeed the Messenger of Allah.' And Allah knows that you are indeed His Messenger, and Allah bears witness that the hypocrites are indeed liars" - meaning in their indication by their speech of their inner thoughts (Damair) - and He said, exalted is He: "And among the people is he whose speech pleases you in the worldly life (Al-Hayat Al-Dunya) and he calls Allah to witness as to what is in his heart (Qalb), and he is the most severe of adversaries (Aladdu Al-Khisam). And when he turns away, he strives throughout the land to cause corruption therein" - the verse - and He said, exalted is He: "And when they meet you, they say: 'We believe,' but when they are alone, they bite their fingertips at you in rage" and He said, exalted is He: "They show off to the people and do not remember Allah except a little, wavering between that." And the verses about them are many. Hypocrisy (Nifaq) used to be abundant in the beginning of Islam among those who entered into the outward appearance of Islam initially for a purpose, and that is something that decreases in our time, but hypocrisy increases among those who secretly slip away from the religion inwardly, so they deny the Garden (Jannah) and the Fire (Nar) and the Abode of the Hereafter (Al-Dar Al-Akhirah) inclining toward the saying of the atheists (Mulhida), or they believe upon the basis of the Sacred Law (Al-Shar') and the rulings inclining toward the people of permissiveness (Ahl Al-Ibaha), or they believe in disbelief (Kufr) or innovation (Bid'ah) while manifesting its opposite, so these are among the hypocrites (Munafiqun) and the ostentatious ones (Mura'iun) who are eternally in the Fire (Nar), and beyond this ostentation there is no ostentation, and the state (Hal) of these is more severe than the state of the open disbelievers (Kuffar Al-Mujahirun), for they have combined the disbelief (Kufr) of the inner self (Batin) and the hypocrisy (Nifaq) of the outward appearance (Zahir).

Vol 4: Intention, Sincerity, and Truthfulness
The second truthfulness (Sidq) is in intention (Niyyah) and will (Iradah), and this returns to sincerity (Ikhlas), which is that there should be no motive (Ba'ith) in his movements (Harakat) and stillness (Sakanat) except Allah the Exalted. For if it is mixed with a taint (Shawb) of the desires (Huzuz) of the Soul (Nafs), the truthfulness of intention (Sidq al-Niyyah) is invalidated, and its possessor may be called a liar (Kadhib), as we have narrated in the virtue of sincerity (Ikhlas) from the hadith of the three when the scholar is asked, 'What did you do with what you knew?' He said, 'I did such and such.' So Allah the Exalted said, 'You have lied (Kadhabta), rather you intended that it be said, so-and-so is a scholar.' The hadith of the three when the scholar was asked, 'What did you do with what you knew?' The hadith has preceded. For He did not call him a liar and did not say to him, 'You did not do,' but He called him a liar in his will (Iradah) and intention (Niyyah). And some have said, 'Truthfulness (Sidq) is the soundness of monotheism (Tawhid) in purpose (Qasd).' Likewise, the saying of Allah the Exalted: 'And Allah bears witness that the hypocrites (Munafiqun) are indeed liars (Kadhibun).' And they had said, 'You are the Messenger of Allah,' and this is truthfulness (Sidq), but their lying (Kadhib) is not from where the tongue (Lisan) speaks, but from where the secret (Damir) of the Heart (Qalb) is. And the accusation of lying (Takdhib) pertains to the report (Khabar), and this saying includes reporting by circumstantial evidence (Qarinah al-Hal), for its possessor shows from himself that he believes what he says, so he lied in his indication by circumstantial evidence (Qarinah al-Hal) of what is in his Heart (Qalb), for he lied in that and did not lie in what he utters. So one of the meanings of truthfulness (Sidq) returns to the purity (Khalus) of intention (Niyyah), which is sincerity (Ikhlas). Thus, every truthful person (Sadiq) must necessarily be sincere (Mukhlis).

The second aspect: that by which the vileness of arrogance (Kibr) is magnified is that it calls to opposing Allah the Exalted in His commands, because the arrogant one, when he hears the truth from a servant (Abd) among the servants of Allah, disdains accepting it and prepares for its denial. Therefore, you see those who debate in matters of religion claiming that they are investigating the secrets of religion, yet they deny each other with the denial of the arrogant. Whenever the truth becomes clear on the tongue of one of them, the other is too proud (Anif) to accept it, and prepares for its denial and schemes to repel it with whatever he can of deception. That is from the character traits of the disbelievers and hypocrites, as Allah the Exalted described them, saying: "And those who disbelieve say: 'Do not listen to this Quran and cause disruption in it that you may overcome.'" So everyone who debates for victory and silencing, not to seize the truth if he attains it, has shared with them in this character trait. Likewise, this is carried over to the pride (Anafah) from accepting admonition, as Allah the Exalted said: "And when it is said to him, 'Fear Allah (Ittaqi Allah),' pride (Al-'Izzah) seizes him with sin." And it is narrated from Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, that he recited it and said: "Indeed we belong to Allah, and indeed to Him we return." A man stood up commanding good (Al-Ma'ruf) and was killed, then another stood up and said: "They kill those who command justice (Al-Qist) among the people," and the arrogant one who opposed him and the one who commanded him were killed out of arrogance. And Ibn Mas'ud said: "It is enough sin for a man when it is said to him, 'Fear Allah (Ittaqi Allah),' and he says: 'Mind your own self!'" And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said to a man: "Eat with your right hand," he said: "I cannot," so the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "May you not be able," and nothing prevented him except his arrogance (Kibr). He said: "So he did not raise it after that," meaning his hand became impaired. Therefore, his arrogance (Takabbur) over the creation is great because it will call him to be arrogant (Takabbur) over the command of Allah. Indeed, Iblis was made an example of this, and what He narrated of his states is only to take lesson from it, for he said: "I am better than him," and this arrogance (Kibr) is by lineage because he said: "I am better than him; You created me from fire and created him from clay." That carried him to refuse the prostration that Allah the Exalted commanded him, and its beginning was arrogance (Kibr) over Adam and envy for him, which dragged him to arrogance (Takabbur) over the command of Allah the Exalted, and that was the cause of his destruction forever. So this is a great affliction from the afflictions of arrogance (Kibr) over the servants. Therefore, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, explained arrogance (Kibr) with these two afflictions when Thabit ibn Qays ibn Shammas asked him, saying: "O Messenger of Allah, I am a man to whom beauty has been made beloved, as you see; is that from arrogance (Kibr)?" The second aspect: that by which the vice of arrogance (Kibr) is magnified is that it calls to disobedience of Allah the Exalted in His commands, because the arrogant one, when he hears the truth from a servant among the servants of Allah, disdains accepting it and prepares for its denial. Therefore, you see those who debate in matters of religion claiming that they are investigating the secrets of religion, yet they deny each other with the denial of the arrogant. Whenever the truth becomes clear on the tongue of one of them, the other disdains accepting it, prepares for its denial, and schemes to repel it with what he can of deception. That is from the character traits of the disbelievers and hypocrites, as Allah the Exalted described them, saying: "And those who disbelieve say: 'Do not listen to this Quran and make noise during it that you may overcome.'" So everyone who debates for victory and silencing, not to seize the truth when he attains it, has shared with them in this character trait. Likewise, this is carried over to the disdain (Anafa) from accepting admonition, as Allah the Exalted said: "And when it is said to him: 'Fear Allah (Taqwa),' pride (Izza) takes him to sin.'" And it is narrated from Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, that he recited it and said: "Indeed we belong to Allah and indeed to Him we will return.' A man stood up commanding good and was killed, then another stood up and said: 'They kill those who command justice among the people,' so the arrogant one who opposed him and the one who commanded him were killed out of arrogance. And Ibn Mas'ud said: 'It is sufficient sin for a man when it is said to him: Fear Allah (Taqwa),' he says: 'Mind your own self!' And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said to a man: 'Eat with your right hand,' he said: 'I cannot,' so the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: 'May you not be able,' nothing prevented him except his arrogance (Kibr).' It is said: 'He never raised it after that,' meaning his hand became impaired. Therefore, his arrogance (Takabbur) over the creation is great because it will call him to arrogance (Takabbur) over the command of Allah. Indeed, Iblis (Satan) was made an example of this, and what is narrated of his conditions is only to take lesson from it, for he said: 'I am better than him,' and this arrogance (Kibr) is by lineage because he said: 'I am better than him, You created me from fire and created him from clay.' That carried him to refrain from the prostration that Allah the Exalted commanded him with, and its beginning was arrogance (Kibr) over Adam and envy for him, that dragged him to arrogance (Takabbur) over the command of Allah the Exalted, so that was the cause of his destruction forever. So this is a calamity from the calamities of arrogance (Kibr) over the servants, great. Therefore, the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, explained arrogance (Kibr) with these two calamities when Thabit ibn Qays ibn Shammas asked him, saying: 'O Messenger of Allah, I am a man to whom beauty has been made beloved as you see, is that from arrogance (Kibr)?' He said, peace be upon him: 'No, but arrogance (Kibr) is from rejecting the truth (Batr al-Haqq) and despising people (Ghams al-Nas).' And in another hadith: 'From belittling the truth (Safah al-Haqq).' And his saying: 'And despising people (Ghams al-Nas)' means looking down upon them and considering them insignificant, and they are servants of Allah, his equals or better than him. So Allah the Exalted revealed: "And among the people is he who sells his soul (Nafs) seeking the pleasure (Rida) of Allah, and Allah is Kind (Ra'uf) to the servants." [103] Hadith: Ali slept on the bed of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), so Allah revealed to Gabriel and Michael: 'I have made brotherhood between you two and made the life of one of you longer than the other.' The hadith is regarding the revelation of His saying, the Exalted: 'And among the people is he who sells (yashri) his soul (nafs) seeking the pleasure (mardat) of Allah.' It was reported by Ahmad in a concise form from the narration of Ibn Abbas: 'He sold (shara) upon his soul (nafs), so he wore the garment of the Prophet (peace be upon him) and then slept in his place.' The hadith does not contain mention of Gabriel and Michael, and I have not found a source for this addition, and in it is Abu Balj, who is disputed, and the hadith is rejected (munkar).

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
If you say: Where is the error in the statement of the disobedient and wicked that Allah is Generous and we hope for His Mercy and forgiveness, and He has said 'I am as My servant thinks of Me, so let him think good of Me' - is this not correct speech with an acceptable outward appearance in the hearts? Know that Satan does not misguide the human except with speech that has an acceptable outward appearance but a rejected inward reality, and were it not for the goodness of its outward appearance, hearts would not be deceived by it. But the Prophet (peace be upon him) uncovered this by saying: 'The intelligent one is he who holds his Soul (Nafs) accountable and works for what is after death, and the foolish one is he who follows his Soul's (Nafs) desires and makes wishes upon Allah.' This is making wishes upon Allah the Exalted, but Satan changed its name and called it: Hope (RajÄ'), until he deceived the ignorant with it. And Allah explained Hope (RajÄ') by saying: 'Indeed, those who have believed and those who have emigrated and striven in the path of Allah - those hope for the mercy of Allah.' Meaning that Hope (RajÄ') is more fitting for them, and this is because He mentioned that the reward of the Hereafter is a wage and recompense for deeds. Allah the Exalted said: 'A recompense for what they used to do' and He said: 'And you will only be given your wages on the Day of Resurrection.' Do you see that one who is hired to repair vessels and is promised a wage for them, and the promiser is generous who fulfills the promise whenever he promises and does not break it but rather increases, then the hired worker comes and breaks the vessels and ruins all of them, then sits waiting for the wage and claims that the hirer is generous - do the intelligent see him in his waiting as a wishful, deceived person or as one who hopes? And this is due to ignorance of the difference between Hope (RajÄ') and delusion.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Fear and Hope
So if the servant (Abd) is diligent in acts of obedience (Taat) and avoids sins (Maasi), he is worthy to expect from the bounty of Allah the completion of blessing (Nimah), and what is the completion of blessing except by entering Paradise. As for the sinner (Aasi), if he repents (Tab) and makes up for all that he has neglected of shortcomings, he is worthy to hope for the acceptance of repentance (Tawbah). And as for before repentance, if he is averse to sin (Ma'siyah), the bad deed (Sayyi'ah) displeases him and the good deed (Hasanah) pleases him, and he blames his soul (Nafs) and reproaches it, and he desires repentance (Tawbah) and yearns for it, he is worthy to hope from Allah for success (Tawfiq) in repentance, because his aversion to sin and his eagerness for repentance run as a cause (Sabab) that may lead to repentance. And as for hope (Rajaa) after the causes are confirmed, and therefore Allah the Exalted said: 'Indeed, those who have believed and those who have emigrated and fought in the cause of Allah - those expect the mercy of Allah' (Quran 2:218). Its meaning is: those deserve to hope for the mercy of Allah, and He did not intend to specify the existence of hope, because others may also hope, but He specified them with deserving hope. As for one who immerses himself in what Allah the Exalted dislikes and does not blame his soul (Nafs) for it nor resolves on repentance (Tawbah) and return, his hope for forgiveness (Maghfirah) is foolishness, like the hope of one who sows seed in barren land and resolves not to tend it with watering or purification.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Love, Longing, and Intimacy
Know that the evidences of the Quran are mutually supporting in that Allah, the Exalted, loves His servant, so it is necessary to know the meaning of that. And let us first present the evidences for His love, for Allah, the Exalted, has said: "Indeed, Allah loves those who constantly repent [al-tawwabin] and He loves those who purify themselves [al-mutatahhirin]." And it has been narrated by Anas from the Prophet, peace be upon him, that he said: "When Allah, the Exalted, loves a servant, sin does not harm him, and the one who repents from sin is like one who has no sin." a.g: For those who swear not to have sexual relations with their wives is a waiting time of four months, but if they return [to normal relations] - then indeed, Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
And if they decide on divorce - then indeed, Allah is Hearing and Knowing.

Divorced women remain in waiting for three periods, and it is not lawful for them to conceal what Allah has created in their wombs if they believe in Allah and the Last Day. And their husbands have more right to take them back in this [period] if they want reconciliation. And due to the wives is similar to what is expected of them, according to what is reasonable. But the men have a degree over them [in responsibility and authority]. And Allah is Exalted in Might and Wise.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
Therefore, some of them excused themselves from marriage and said: 'I am afflicted with my own soul (Nafs), so how can I add another soul (Nafs) to it?' As it is said: 'The mouse's burrow will not accommodate it when it attaches the broom to its tail.' Likewise, Ibrahim ibn Adham, may Allah have mercy on him, excused himself and said: 'I will not deceive a woman with myself, nor do I have need for them,' meaning from fulfilling their rights (Huquq), protecting them, and giving them enjoyment, and I am incapable of that. Likewise, Bishr excused himself and said: 'What prevents me from marriage is the saying of Allah the Exalted: "And for them is like that which is upon them with kindness (bil-ma'ruf)."' And he used to say: 'If I were to provide for a chicken, I would fear that I would become a toll-collector on the bridge.'

And it is not lawful for you to take anything of what you have given them unless both fear that they will not be able to keep [within] the limits of Allah. Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
The twelfth [section] is on divorce (Talaq), and it should be known that it is permissible (Mubah) but it is the most detested of permissible things to Allah, the Exalted. It is only permissible when there is no harm (Itha') in falsehood, and whenever he divorces her, he has harmed her. Harming others is not permitted except due to a transgression (Jinayah) from her side or a necessity (Darurah) from his side. Allah, the Exalted, said: 'If they obey you, then do not seek a way against them' (Quran 4:34), meaning do not seek a stratagem for separation. And if her father dislikes her, let him divorce her. Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: 'I had a wife whom I loved, and my father disliked her and ordered me to divorce her. So I consulted the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and he said: O Ibn Umar, divorce your wife.' This indicates that the right of the parent takes precedence, but a parent who dislikes her without a corrupt purpose, like Umar. And whenever she harms her husband and exposes [faults] to his family, she is a transgressor. Likewise, if she is of bad character (Sayi'at al-Khuluq) or corrupt in religion (Fasidat al-Deen). Ibn Mas'ud said regarding the saying of Allah, the Exalted: 'And they should not leave except that they commit a clear immorality' (Quran 65:1), whenever she exposes [faults] to his family and harms her husband, that is an immorality (Fahishah). This is intended during the waiting period (Iddah), but it is an alert to the intended meaning. And if the harm is from the husband, she may redeem herself by giving wealth, and it is disliked for the man to take from her more than what he gave, for that is injustice (Ijhaf) to her and oppression (Tahammul) upon her and trading on the private part (Bid'). Allah, the Exalted, said: 'Then there is no blame upon them for what she gives to ransom herself' (Quran 2:229), returning what he took or less is suitable for the ransom (Fidya'). If she asks for divorce without any wrongdoing, she is sinful (Athimah). The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Any woman who asks her husband for divorce without any wrongdoing will not smell the fragrance of Paradise.' In another wording: 'Paradise is forbidden to her.' In another wording: 'He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: The women who seek redemption (Mukhtali'at) are the hypocrites (Munafiqat).'

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Miserliness
Indeed, if you say: "Why did 'Isa (Jesus), peace be upon him, abandon marriage despite its virtue, and if the superior path is to be free for the worship of Allah, then why did our Messenger, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, take many wives?" Then know that the superior path is to combine the two for the one who is capable, whose spiritual aspiration [himma] is strong and whose rank [manzila] is elevated, so that no preoccupation distracts him from Allah. And our Messenger, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, took the path of strength and combined the virtue of worship ['ibada] and marriage. Indeed, he was with nine women, and it is also narrated from him that he had eleven, while being completely devoted to the worship of Allah. And the fulfillment of natural desire [watar] through marriage was, in his case, no impediment.

a.g: And if he has divorced her [for the third time], then she is not lawful to him afterward until [after] she marries a husband other than him. And if the latter husband divorces her [or dies], there is no blame upon the woman and her former husband for returning to each other if they think that they can keep [within] the limits of Allah. These are the limits of Allah, which He makes clear to a people who know.

And when you divorce women and they have [nearly] fulfilled their term, either retain them according to acceptable terms or release them according to acceptable terms, and do not keep them, intending harm, to transgress [against them]. And whoever does that has certainly wronged himself. And do not take the verses of Allah in jest. And remember the favor of Allah upon you and what has been revealed to you of the Book and wisdom by which He instructs you. And fear Allah and know that Allah is Knowing of all things.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
The encouragement of marriage: As for from the verses, indeed Allah the Exalted said: 'And marry the unmarried among you' - and this is a command. And He said: 'And when you divorce women and they have [nearly] fulfilled their term, do not prevent them from remarrying their [former] husbands if they agree among themselves on an acceptable basis' - and this is a prohibition of prevention (al-'adl) and a forbiddance from it. And He said in describing the messengers and praising them: 'And We have already sent messengers before you and assigned to them wives and descendants' - so He mentioned that in the context of bestowing favor and showing excellence. And He praised His allies by asking for that in supplication, so He said: 'And those who say, "Our Lord, grant us from among our wives and offspring comfort to our eyes"' - the verse. And it is said that Allah the Exalted did not mention in His Book from the prophets except the married ones, so they said: Indeed, Yahya (peace be upon him) married but did not have intercourse; it is said he did that only to attain excellence and establish the Sunnah, and it is said to lower the gaze. And as for 'Isa (peace be upon him), he will marry when he descends to the earth and will have children.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
Indeed, from what is incumbent upon her of the rights of marriage [nikah] when her husband dies is that she not observe mourning [tahhaddud] for him more than four months and ten, and that she avoid perfume [tayyib] and adornment [zinah] in this period. Zaynab bint Abi Salamah said: I entered upon Umm Habibah, the wife of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, when her father, Abu Sufyan ibn Harb, died. She called for perfume [tayyib] containing a yellow dye of khuluq or other, and anointed a young girl with it, then touched her own cheeks with it. Then she said: By Allah, I have no need for perfume [tayyib], except that I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "It is not lawful [halal] for a woman who believes in Allah and the Last Day [al-Yawm al-Akhir] to observe mourning [tahhaddud] for a deceased person more than three days, except for her husband: four months and ten."

Vol 4: Watchfulness and Self-Examination
But no day passes without a new important matter and an occurring incident that has a new ruling, and Allah has a right upon him in that. This increases for one who is occupied with something from worldly affairs like governance, trade, or teaching, for rarely does a day pass without a new incident that requires fulfilling Allah's right in it. So he must stipulate upon himself uprightness in it and submission to the truth in its courses, and warn it of the consequence of neglect, and admonish it as a runaway rebellious slave is admonished. For the Soul (Nafs) is by nature rebellious against acts of worship, resistant to servitude, but admonition and discipline affect it, and remembrance (Dhikr), for the reminder benefits the believers. This and what runs its course is the first station of vigilance with the Soul (Nafs), which is self-accounting before action. Self-accounting is sometimes after action and sometimes before it for warning. Allah the Exalted said: 'And know that Allah knows what is in your souls (Anfusikum), so beware of Him.' This is for the future. And every looking into quantity and measure to know increase and decrease is called self-accounting. So looking into what is before the servant in his day to know his increase from his decrease is from self-accounting. Vol 4: Watchfulness and Self-Examination
And He (Exalted is He) said: 'And know that Allah knows what is in your souls (Anfusikum) so beware of Him.' So the possessors of insight from among the servants recognized that Allah (Exalted is He) is lying in wait for them and that they will be scrutinized in the accounting and will be demanded with the weight of an atom from the passing thoughts (Khatarat) and glances (Lahazat). And they realized that nothing will save them from these dangers except adhering to self-accounting (Muhasabah) and truthful self-observation (Muraqabah) and demanding from the soul (Nafs) in the breaths and movements and accounting it for the passing thoughts and glances. For whoever accounts his soul before being accounted for, his accounting on the Day of Resurrection will be lightened, and his answer will be present at the questioning, and his return and destination will be good. And whoever does not account his soul, his regrets will persist and his pauses in the arenas of the Day of Resurrection will be prolonged, and his evil deeds will lead him to disgrace and contempt. When this was unveiled to them, they knew that nothing will save them from it except obedience to Allah, and He has commanded them with patience (Sabr) and spiritual vigilance (Murabatah), so He (Mighty and Majestic is He) said: 'O you who believe, be patient and endure and be vigilant, so they made their souls vigilant first with mutual stipulation (Musharatah), then with self-observation (Muraqabah), then with self-accounting (Muhasabah), then with self-punishment (Mu'aqabah), then with spiritual struggle (Mujahadah), then with self-reproof (Mu'atabah). So there were for them in spiritual vigilance six stations, and it is necessary to explain them and clarify their reality and virtue and detail the works in them, and the foundation of that is self-accounting. But every accounting is after mutual stipulation and self-observation, and it is followed upon loss by self-reproof and self-punishment. So let us mention the explanation of these stations, and with Allah is success.'

And now let us mention the virtue of forgiveness and benevolence. The Virtue of Forgiveness and Benevolence. Know that the meaning of forgiveness (Al-'Afw) is that one has a right due, then he drops it and absolves from it regarding retaliation or penalty, and it is different from forbearance (Al-Hilm) and suppressing anger (Kazm Al-Ghaiz); therefore, we have singled it out. Allah the Exalted said: "Take forgiveness and enjoin what is good and turn away from the ignorant." And Allah the Exalted said: "And that you forgive is nearer to piety (Al-Taqwa)." And the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: "Threeâ€”by the One in Whose Hand is my soul (Nafs), if I were to swear an oath, I would swear upon them: No wealth decreases from charity, so give charity; and no man forgives an injustice seeking by it the Face of Allah except that Allah increases him in honor (Izz) on the Day of Resurrection; and no man opens upon himself a door of asking except that Allah opens upon him a door of poverty." And he (peace be upon him) said: "Humility does not increase the servant (Al-'Abd) except in elevation, so be humble and Allah will elevate you; and forgiveness does not increase the servant except in honor, so forgive and Allah will honor you; and charity does not increase wealth except in abundance, so give charity and Allah will have mercy on you." And 'A'isha (may Allah be pleased with her) said: "I never saw the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) seeking retaliation for an injustice done to him as long as it did not violate the prohibitions of Allah, but if something from the prohibitions of Allah was violated, he was the most severe among them in anger regarding that, and he was never given a choice between two matters except he chose the easiest of them as long as it was not a sin." And 'Uqbah said: "I met the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) one day and I hastened to him and took his hand, or he hastened to me and took my hand, and he said: 'O 'Uqbah, shall I not inform you of the best character traits of the people of this world and the Hereafter: You maintain ties with one who cuts you off, you give to one who deprives you, and you forgive one who wrongs you.'" And he (peace be upon him) said: "Moses (upon him be peace) said: 'O Lord, which of Your servants is most honorable to You?' He said: 'The one who, when he has power, forgives.'" Likewise, Abu Al-Darda' was asked about the most honorable of people, and he said: "The one who forgives when he has power, so forgive and Allah will honor you." And a man came to the Prophet (peace be upon him) complaining.

And another group said: Rather, we enter and rely (Tawakkul) and do not flee from the decree (Qadar) of Allah the Exalted and do not flee from death, so we become like those about whom Allah the Exalted said: 'Have you not seen those who left their homes while they were thousands, fearing death?' So they returned to Umar and asked him about his opinion, and he said: We return and do not enter upon the plague, and those who disagreed with his opinion said to him: Do you flee from the decree (Qadar) of Allah the Exalted? Umar said: Yes, we flee from the decree (Qadar) of Allah to the decree (Qadar) of Allah, then he gave them an example and said: What do you think if one of you had sheep and descended into a valley that has two branches, one fertile and the other barren, is it not that if he grazes the fertile one, he grazes it by the decree (Qadar) of Allah the Exalted, and if he grazes the barren one, he grazes it by the decree (Qadar) of Allah the Exalted? They said: Yes, then he sought Abd al-Rahman ibn Awf to ask him about his opinion - and he was absent - and when morning came, Abd al-Rahman came and Umar asked him about that, and he said: I have something in this matter, O Commander of the Faithful, that I heard from the Messenger of Allah ï·º, and Umar said: Allah is the Greatest, and Abd al-Rahman said: I heard the Messenger of Allah ï·º say: 'When you hear of a plague in a land, do not go forward to it, and when it occurs in a land and you are in it, do not leave it fleeing from it.' So Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, rejoiced at that and praised Allah the Exalted since it agreed with his opinion, and he returned from al-Jabiyah with the people.

Vol 2: Etiquette of Marriage
And due to the love (Mahabbah) of Allah the Exalted for the preservation of souls (Nufus), He commanded feeding and urged upon it, and expressed it through the worship (Ibadah) of lending, saying: 'Who is it that would loan Allah a goodly loan (Qardan Hasan) so He may multiply it for him many times over?' If you say: your statement that the preservation of offspring and soul is beloved implies that their annihilation is hated before Allah, and this is a distinction between death and life in relation to the will (Iradah) of Allah the Exalted, and it is known that everything is by the decree (Mashiyyah) of Allah, and indeed Allah is free from need of the worlds, so from where is distinguished before Him their death from their life or their preservation from their annihilation? Know that this statement is truth intended by it falsehood, for what we have mentioned does not contradict attributing all existents to the will (Iradah) of Allah, their good and evil, benefit and harm, but love (Mahabbah) and hatred (Karahiyyah) are opposites, and both do not oppose the will (Iradah), for sometimes a willed thing is hated and sometimes a willed thing is beloved. Sins (Ma'asi) are hated, and they, with the hatred, are willed, and acts of obedience (Ta'at) are willed and intended to be willed, beloved, and pleasing. As for disbelief (Kufr) and evil, we do not say it is pleasing and beloved, but it is willed.

And a group has been deceived by such an illusion and took the path of permissiveness and said: 'Indeed Allah the Exalted is independent of our worship and of borrowing from us, so what meaning is there to His saying: "Who is it that would loan Allah a good loan (Qardan Hasan) so He may multiply it for him many times over?"' And if Allah willed to feed the poor, He would feed them, so there is no need for us to spend our wealth on them, as Allah the Exalted said narrating from the disbelievers: "And when it is said to them, 'Spend from that which Allah has provided for you,' the disbelievers say to the believers, 'Should we feed one whom, if Allah had willed, He would have fed?'" And they also said: "If Allah had willed, we would not have associated [partners with Him] nor would our fathers." So look how they were truthful in their speech and how they perished by their truthfulness. Glory be to the One who, when He wills, destroys with truth, and when He wills, makes happy with ignorance; He misleads many thereby and guides many thereby. These people, when they thought they were employed for the sake of the poor and the needyâ€”exalted is Allahâ€”then said: 'We have no share in the poor, and Allah has no share in us or in our wealth, whether we spend or withhold,' they perished just as the boy perished when he thought the father's purpose was to employ him for the sake of the slaves, and he did not realize that the intended purpose was the establishment of the attribute of knowledge in his self (Nafs) and its confirmation in his heart (Qalb) so that it would be the cause of his happiness in this world. And that was from the father as gentleness with him in drawing him toward what contains his happiness. So this example clarifies for you the misguidance of those who strayed from this path.

If you say: Indeed, the Sacred Law (Sharia) has urged upon works (A'mal) and exaggerated in mentioning their virtue until it sought alms (Sadaqat) by His saying: "Who is it that would loan Allah a goodly loan (Qardan Hasan) so He may multiply it for him many times over?" (Quran 2:245) and He the Exalted said: "And He accepts the alms (Sadaqat)" (Quran 9:104), so how can the action (Fi'l) and spending (Infaq) not be the best? Then know that when the physician praises the medicine, it does not indicate that the medicine is desired for itself or that it is better than the health (Sihha) and healing (Shifa) attained through it, but rather the works (A'mal) are a treatment (Ilaj) for the disease (Marad) of the hearts (Qulub), and the disease of the hearts is something that is mostly not felt, so it is like leprosy (Baras) on the face of one who has no mirror with him, for he does not feel it, and even if it is mentioned to him, he does not believe it. The way with him is to exaggerate in praising washing the face with rose water (Ma' al-Ward), for example, if rose water removes the leprosy, until he is incited by the excessive praise to persist in it, and thus his disease is removed. For if it were mentioned to him that the intended purpose is the removal of leprosy from your face, perhaps he would abandon the treatment and claim that his face has no defect. And let us give an example closer than this: We say: He has a child whom he taught knowledge (Ilm) and the Quran, and he wanted to establish that in his memory (Hifz) so that it does not vanish from him, and he knew that if he ordered him to repeat (Takrir) and study (Dirasa) so that it remains preserved for him, he would say, "It is preserved, and I have no need for repetition and study," because he thinks that what he memorizes at present remains so forever. And he had slaves, so he ordered the child to teach the slaves and promised him for that with goodness, so that his motivation (Da'iya) becomes abundant through much repetition by teaching. Perhaps the poor boy thinks that the intended purpose is teaching the slaves the Quran and that he has attained.

a.g: Have you not considered the assembly of the Children of Israel after [the time of] Moses when they said to a prophet of theirs, "Send to us a king, and we will fight in the way of Allah "? He said, "Would you perhaps refrain from fighting if fighting was prescribed for you?" They said, "And why should we not fight in the cause of Allah when we have been driven out from our homes and from our children?" But when fighting was prescribed for them, they turned away, except for a few of them. And Allah is Knowing of the wrongdoers.

And their prophet said to them, "Indeed, Allah has sent to you Saul as a king." They said, "How can he have kingship over us while we are more worthy of kingship than him and he has not been given any measure of wealth?" He said, "Indeed, Allah has chosen him over you and has increased him abundantly in knowledge and stature. And Allah gives His sovereignty to whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing [in favor] and Knowing."

a.g: And their prophet said to them, "Indeed, a sign of his kingship is that the chest will come to you in which is assurance from your Lord and a remnant of what the family of Moses and the family of Aaron had left, carried by the angels. Indeed in that is a sign for you, if you are believers."

And when Saul went forth with the soldiers, he said, "Indeed, Allah will be testing you with a river. So whoever drinks from it is not of me, and whoever does not taste it is indeed of me, excepting one who takes [from it] in the hollow of his hand." But they drank from it, except a [very] few of them. Then when he had crossed it along with those who believed with him, they said, "There is no power for us today against Goliath and his soldiers." But those who were certain that they would meet Allah said, "How many a small company has overcome a large company by permission of Allah. And Allah is with the patient."

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
The sixth [form of pride] is pride in the multitude of numbers of children, servants, youths, tribe, relatives, supporters, and followers, as the disbelievers said: 'We are more in wealth and children,' and as the believers said on the day of Hunayn: 'We will not be defeated today due to fewness.' Its cure is what we mentioned regarding arrogance, which is to reflect on his weakness and their weakness, and that all of them are weak slaves who possess for themselves neither harm nor benefit. 'How many a small group has overcome a large group by the permission of Allah (Bismillah).' Then how can he be proud of them when they will separate from him when he dies, and he will be buried in his grave humbled, alone, with no family, child, relative, intimate friend, or tribesman accompanying him? They will surrender him to decay, snakes, scorpions, and worms, and they will not avail him anything in his most needy times from them. Likewise, they will flee from him on the Day of Resurrection (Yawm al-Qiyamah): 'The day when a man will flee from his brother, his mother, his father, his wife, and his sons' [the verse]. So what good is there in one who leaves you in your most severe states and flees from you? And how can you be proud of him when he does not benefit you in the grave, the Resurrection (al-Qiyamah), and on the Bridge (al-Sirat) regarding your deeds and the favor of Allah the Exalted? So how can you rely on one who does not benefit you, and forget the blessings of the One who possesses your benefit, harm, death, and life?

As for honor (Al-'Izz) and status (Al-Jah), through them a person repels from himself humiliation (Al-Dhull) and oppression (Al-Dhaim), and no Muslim can do without it, for he is not free from an enemy who harms him and an oppressor who disturbs his knowledge (Ilm), his action (Amal), and his leisure, and occupies his heart (Qalb), and his heart is his capital. These distractions are only repelled by honor and status, and therefore it is said: religion (Al-Deen) and authority (Al-Sultan) are twins. Allah the Exalted said: 'And if Allah did not repel people, some by means of others, the earth would have been corrupted.' And the meaning of status (Al-Jah) is nothing but mastery over hearts (Qulub), just as the meaning of wealth (Al-Ghina) is nothing but mastery over dirhams, and whoever masters dirhams, the masters of hearts are subjugated to him to repel harm from him. So just as one needs a roof to repel rain from him, a garment to repel cold from him, and a dog to repel the wolf from his livestock, he also needs someone to repel evil from him through him. And with this intention, the prophets who had no kingdom or dominion would observe the rulers and seek status with them, and likewise the scholars of religion, not with the intention of taking from their treasuries and monopolizing and accumulating in the world by following them. ğŸ“– Vol 1: Invocations and Supplications
Indeed, the most majestic of all that is known [ma'lumat] is God, the Exalted. Therefore, it is without doubt that the finest and most noble of sciences [ulum] is the knowledge [ma'rifa] of God, the Exalted. And He has addressed all of creation, saying, Mighty and Majestic is He: "And you have not been given of knowledge [ilm] except a little." Nay, were the people of the earth and the heavens to gather to encompass His knowledge [ilm] and His wisdom in the detailed creation of an ant or a mosquito, they would not attain to a tenth of a tenth of that. "And they encompass not a thing of His knowledge [ilm] except by what He wills." And the small measure which all creatures know, they know it only by His teaching. If the beauty [jamal] of the world [alam] and its nobility is a beloved matter, and if it is in itself an adornment and a perfection for the One described by it, then it is not fitting that anyone be loved for this reason except God, the Exalted. The sciences [ulum] of the scholars are ignorance [jahl] in comparison to His knowledge [ilm]. Nay, whoever knows the most knowledgeable person of his time and the most ignorant person of his time finds it impossible to love the more ignorant one because of his knowledge [ilm] and abandon the more knowledgeable one, even though the more ignorant one is not devoid of some knowledge [ilm] that his livelihood demands. And the disparity between the knowledge [ilm] of God and the knowledge [ilm] of all creatures is greater than the disparity between the knowledge [ilm] of the most knowledgeable of creatures and the most ignorant of them. For the most knowledgeable only surpasses the most ignorant by a limited, finite number of sciences [ulum] which it is possible for the most ignorant to attain through effort and striving. But the superiority of the knowledge [ilm] of God, the Exalted, over the sciences [ulum] of all creatures is beyond limit, for His known things [ma'lumat] are without end, and the known things [ma'lumat] of creatures are finite.

a.g: Or [consider such an example] as the one who passed by a township which had fallen into ruin. He said, "How will Allah bring this to life after its death?" So Allah caused him to die for a hundred years; then He revived him. He said, "How long have you remained?" The man said, "I have remained a day or part of a day." He said, "Rather, you have remained one hundred years. Look at your food and your drink; it has not changed with time. And look at your donkey; and We will make you a sign for the people. And look at the bones [of this donkey] - how We raise them and then We cover them with flesh." And when it became clear to him, he said, "I know that Allah is over all things competent."

And [mention] when Abraham said, "My Lord, show me how You give life to the dead." [Allah] said, "Have you not believed?" He said, "Yes, but [I ask] only that my heart may be satisfied." [Allah] said, "Take four birds and commit them to yourself. Then [after slaughtering them] put on each hill a portion of them; then call them - they will come [flying] to you in haste. ğŸ“– Vol 4: Tawhid and Trust
Therefore, Reliance (Tawakkul) is not complete except with strength of the Heart (Qalb) and strength of Certainty (Yaqeen) together, for through them the tranquility (Sukun) of the Heart (Qalb) and its peace (Itmi'nan) are attained. Tranquility (Sukun) in the Heart (Qalb) is one thing and Certainty (Yaqeen) is another thing, for how much Certainty (Yaqeen) there is without peace (Itmi'nan) with it, as Allah the Exalted said to Ibrahim, peace be upon him: 'Have you not believed? He said: Yes, but so that my Heart (Qalb) may be at peace (Yatma'inn).' So he sought to witness the revival of the dead with his own eye so that it would be established in his imagination, for the Soul (Nafs) follows the imagination and is at peace (Tatma'inn) with it, and it is not at peace (Tatma'inn) with Certainty (Yaqeen) at the beginning of its affair until it reaches in the Hereafter the degree of the Soul at Peace (Nafs al-Mutma'innah); and that does not occur at the beginning at all. And how many are at peace (Mutma'inn) without Certainty (Yaqeen) for them, like the rest of the people of religions and schools, for the Jew is at peace (Mutma'inn) in his Heart (Qalb) with his Judaism, and likewise the Christian, and they have no Certainty (Yaqeen) at all, and they only follow conjecture (Zann) and what the Souls (Anfus) desire, and indeed guidance (Huda) has come to them from their Lord, which is the cause of Certainty (Yaqeen), except that they turn away from it. Therefore, cowardice (Jubn) and boldness (Jara'ah) are instincts, and Certainty (Yaqeen) does not benefit with them, so they are one of the causes that oppose the state of Reliance (Tawakkul), just as weakness of Certainty (Yaqeen) in the four traits is one of the causes. And when these causes are gathered, Trust (Thiqah) in Allah the Exalted is attained. And it has been said: It is written in the Torah: Cursed is he whose trust (Thiqah) is in a human like him. And He, peace be upon him, said: 'Whoever seeks might through slaves, Allah the Exalted will humiliate him.' Vol 4: Meditation
If you say that their difference is due to the difference in their seeds and origins, then when was there in the kernel a palm tree encircled with clusters of fresh dates, and when was there in a single grain seven ears, in every ear a hundred? Then look at the land of the deserts and search its surface and interior, and you will see it as similar dust. But when water is sent down upon it, it quivers and swells and brings forth from every delightful pair different colors and plants, similar and dissimilar, each one having a taste, scent, color, and shape differing from the other. So look at their multitude, the difference in their kinds, the abundance of their forms, then the difference in the natures of plants and the abundance of their benefits, and how Allah the Exalted has deposited in them strange beneficial medicines: this plant nourishes, this strengthens, this gives life, this kills, this cools, this heats, this when it reaches the stomach suppresses the yellow bile from the depths of the veins, this transforms into yellow bile, this suppresses the phlegm and black bile, this transforms into them, this purifies the blood, this dissolves blood, this gladdens, this induces sleep, this strengthens, this weakens. Not a leaf nor a straw grows from the earth except that in it are benefits that humans cannot fully comprehend. And each one of these plants requires the farmer in its cultivation a specific action: the palm trees favor generosity, they are pruned; the crops are cleared of weeds and thickets; some of it is propagated by scattering the seed in the earth, some by planting branches, some is grafted onto trees. And if we wanted to mention the differences in the genera of plants, their types, their benefits, their states, and their wonders, the days would not suffice in describing that, so suffice it for you...

a.g: Kind speech and forgiveness are better than charity followed by injury. And Allah is Free of need and Forbearing.

O you who have believed, do not invalidate your charities with reminders or injury as does one who spends his wealth [only] to be seen by the people and does not believe in Allah and the Last Day. His example is like that of a [large] smooth stone upon which is dust and is hit by a downpour that leaves it bare. They are unable [to keep] anything of what they have earned. And Allah does not guide the disbelieving people.

The fifth duty: that he does not spoil his charity with reminding and harm. Allah the Exalted said: 'Do not invalidate your charities with reminding and harm.' And they differed regarding the reality of reminding and harm. It was said: reminding is to mention it, and harm is to display it. And Sufyan said: whoever reminds, his charity is spoiled. He was asked: How is reminding? He said: that he mentions it and speaks about it. And it was said: reminding is to employ him with the giving, and harm is to reproach him with poverty. And it was said: reminding is to be arrogant toward him because of his giving, and harm is to rebuke him or scold him with the asking. And the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Allah does not accept the charity of a remembrancer.' And in my view, reminding has an origin and a planting place, and it is from the states (Ahwal) of the Heart (Qalb) and its attributes, then it branches out into apparent states on the tongue and the limbs. So its origin is that he sees himself as a benefactor to him and a bestower of favor upon him, and his right is to see the poor person as a benefactor to him by accepting the right of Allah the Exalted from him, which is his purification and his salvation from the Fire, and that if he were to accept it, he would remain indebted by it. So his right is that the poor person receives it from him, since he made his hand a deputy for Allah the Exalted in receiving the right of Allah the Exalted. The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'Indeed, charity falls into the hand of Allah the Exalted before it falls into the hand of the asker.' So let him realize that he is surrendering to Allah the Exalted his right, and the poor person is taking from Allah the Exalted his provision after its arrival to Allah the Exalted. Indeed, Allah the Exalted has said, "Do not invalidate your charities with reminders of your generosity [al-mann] or injury [al-adha]." And the reminder of generosity [al-mann] is the result of magnifying the charity, and magnifying the deed is self-admiration [al-'ujb]. Thus, it is made clear by this that self-admiration [al-'ujb] is most blameworthy. **Clarifying the Affliction of Self-Admiration [al-'ujb]** Know that the afflictions [afat] of self-admiration [al-'ujb] are many. For indeed, self-admiration [al-'ujb] calls to forgetting and neglecting sins. So some of his sins he does not remember nor examine, due to his assumption that he is free from the need to examine them, and thus he forgets them. And what he does remember of them, he considers insignificant and does not magnify, so he does not strive to make up for it and rectify it. Rather, he assumes it will be forgiven for him. As for acts of worship [al-'ibadat] and deeds [al-a'mal], he magnifies them, boasts with them, and reminds Allah of His favor [al-mann] by doing them. And he forgets Allah's favor [ni'mah] upon him in granting success [al-tawfiq] and enabling him to perform them. Then, when he admires them, he becomes blind to their defects [afat]. And whoever does not examine the defects [afat] of deeds [al-a'mal], most of his striving is wasted. For indeed, outward deeds [al-a'mal al-zahirah], if they are not pure [khalisah] and clear of impurities, rarely benefit. Only one who is overcome by apprehension [al-ishfaq] and fear [al-khawf], not self-admiration [al-'ujb], examines them. And the self-admirer [al-mu'jab] is deceived by himself and his own opinion [ra'y], and feels secure from the plan [makr] of Allah and His punishment. He assumes he has a station with Allah and that he has a claim [haqq] and a favor [mannah] with Allah due to his deeds [a'mal], which are themselves a favor [ni'mah] and a gift from His gifts. Self-admiration [al-'ujb] leads him to praise himself, commend himself, and declare himself pure. And if he admires his own opinion [ra'y], his deed ['amal], and his intellect ['aql], that prevents him from benefiting, from seeking counsel [al-istisharah], and from asking. So he becomes self-reliant with his soul [nafs] and his opinion [ra'y], and he scorns asking one who is more knowledgeable than him. Perhaps he admires an erroneous opinion [ra'y] that occurred to him, so he rejoices that it is from his own thoughts, and does not rejoice in the thoughts of others, so he insists upon it and does not listen to the advice or admonition of an admonisher. Rather, he looks at others with the eye of considering them ignorant, and he persists in his error. If his opinion [ra'y] is concerning a religious matter, especially that which pertains to the fundamentals of creed [usul al-'aqa'id], he is destroyed by it. Yet if he were to suspect himself, not trust his opinion [ra'y], seek illumination by the light [nur] of the Qur'an, seek aid from the scholars of the religion ['ulama' al-din], and persist in studying knowledge [al-'ilm] and follow the practice of asking the people of insight [ahl al-basirah], that would lead him to the truth [al-haqq]. This and its like are from the afflictions [afat] of self-admiration [al-'ujb], and for that reason it is among the destroyers [al-muhlikat]. And it was said to Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: When is a man sinful? She said: When he thinks he is doing good. And the reminder of favor results from magnifying the charity, and magnifying the action is self-admiration (Al-'Ujb). So it became clear by this that self-admiration (Al-'Ujb) is very blameworthy.

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
The third state is after completion of the work, for one needs patience (Sabr) regarding revealing it and displaying it for reputation and showing off (Riya'), and patience regarding looking at it with the eye of wonder and regarding everything that invalidates his work and nullifies its effect, as the Exalted said: 'And do not invalidate your deeds' and as the Exalted said: 'O you who have believed, do not invalidate your charities with reminders of favor or injury like the one who spends his wealth to be seen by the people and does not believe in Allah and the Last Day. So his example is like that of a smooth stone upon which is dust and is hit by a downpour that leaves it bare. They are unable to keep anything of what they have earned. And Allah does not guide the disbelieving people.' So whoever does not have patience after charity regarding reminders of favor and injury has indeed invalidated his work.

a.g: And the example of those who spend their wealth seeking means to the approval of Allah and assuring [reward for] themselves is like a garden on high ground which is hit by a downpour - so it yields its fruits in double. And [even] if it is not hit by a downpour, then a drizzle [is sufficient]. And Allah, of what you do, is Seeing.

Would one of you like to have a garden of palm trees and grapevines underneath which rivers flow in which he has from every fruit? But he is afflicted with old age and has weak offspring, and it is hit by a whirlwind containing fire and is burned. Thus does Allah make clear to you [His] verses that you might give thought.

O you who have believed, spend from the good things which you have earned and from that which We have produced for you from the earth. And do not aim toward the defective therefrom, spending [from that] while you would not take it [yourself] except with closed eyes. And know that Allah is Free of need and Praiseworthy.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Zakat
The Seventh Duty: That he selects from his wealth its best, most beloved to him, most noble, and purest, for Allah the Exalted is Pure (Tayyib) and does not accept except the pure. And if the expenditure is from doubtful sources, perhaps it is not absolutely his property, so it does not achieve its proper place. In the hadith of Aban from Anas ibn Malik: 'Blessed is the servant who spends from wealth he earned without disobedience.' And if the expenditure is not from good wealth, it is from bad manners, for he may keep the good for himself, his servant, or his family, thus having preferred over Allah the Exalted others. If he did this with a guest and presented to him the worst food in his house, it would fill his chest with resentmentâ€”this if his view is towards Allah the Exalted. And if his view is towards himself and his reward in the Hereafter, then he is not rational who prefers others over himself, and he has nothing from his wealth except what he gave in charity and thus preserved or ate and thus consumed. And what he eats is satisfaction of desire in the present, so it is not from rationality to limit the view to the immediate and abandon saving. And Allah the Exalted has said: 'O you who have believed, spend from the good things which you have earned and from that which We have produced for you from the earth. And do not aim at the bad therefrom, spending [from that] while you would not take it [yourselves] except with closed eyes (Tughmidu) in it.' That is, do not take it except with dislike and shame (Haya'), which is the meaning of closing the eyes (Al-Ighmadh), so do not prefer with it your Lord. And in the report: 'A dirham preceded a hundred thousand dirhams.' That is by a person giving it out while it is from the most lawful of his wealth and its best, issuing from contentment and joy in giving. And he may give a hundred thousand dirhams from what he dislikes of his wealth, indicating that he does not prefer Allah the Exalted with anything he loves. And with that, Allah the Exalted censured a people who assigned to Allah what they dislike, so He said: 'And they assign to Allah that which they dislike, and their tongues assert the lie that they will have the best. No!' Some reciters paused at the negation to refute them, then began and said: 'Indeed, for them is the Fire.' That is, earning for themâ€”their assigning to Allah what they dislikeâ€”the Fire.

a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol 3: Wonders of the Heart
If you ask: "Is there a remedy [dawa'] that benefits in turning the heart [qalb] away from relying upon the apparent causes [al-asbab al-zahira] and having good thoughts [husn al-zann] of God, the Exalted, in facilitating the hidden causes [al-asbab al-khafiyya]?" Then I say: Yes, it is that you know that bad thoughts [su' al-zann] are the prompting [talqin] of Satan, and good thoughts [husn al-zann] are the prompting [talqin] of God, the Exalted. God, the Exalted, said: "Satan threatens you with poverty and commands you to immorality, while God promises you forgiveness from Him and bounty." Indeed, man, by his nature, is captivated by listening to the threats of Satan, and for that reason it is said: "He who is anxious is addicted to bad thoughts [su' al-zann]." And when cowardice [al-jubn] and weakness of the heart [qalb] are added to it, along with observing those who rely upon the apparent causes [al-asbab al-zahira] and are driven by them, then bad thoughts [su' al-zann] prevail and reliance [tawakkul] is completely nullified. Nay, even seeing provision [al-rizq] as coming from the hidden causes [al-asbab al-khafiyya] also nullifies reliance [tawakkul].

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Poverty and Abstinence
So the fear of the future, when Allah has given you the sustenance of your day for you and your dependents, is only from weakness of certainty (Yaqin) and listening to the frightening of Satan (Shaytan). And He, the Exalted, has said: "So do not fear them and fear Me if you are believers." And He, the Mighty and Majestic, has said: "Satan promises you poverty and commands you to indecency (Fahsha'), and Allah promises you forgiveness from Him and bounty." And asking (Sual) is from the indecency (Fahsha') that is permitted by necessity, and the state of one who asks for a need deferred beyond his day, even if it is from what is needed in the year, is more severe than the state of one who possesses inherited wealth and saves it for a need beyond the year. Both are permitted in the apparent legal opinion (Fatwa), but they stem from love of the world (Dunya) and long hope (Tul al-Amal) and lack of trust (Thiqa) in the bounty of Allah, and this characteristic is from the mothers of destroyers. We ask Allah for good success through His gentleness and generosity.

ğŸ“– Vol 1: Secrets of Zakat
The third duty: Secrecy, for that is farther from ostentation (Riya) and reputation-seeking (Sum'ah). The Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'The best charity (Sadaqah) is the effort of the poor person given to a poor person in secret.' And some scholars said: 'Three are from the treasures of righteousness, among them is hiding charity.' And it has also been narrated with a chain of transmission, and the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Verily, a servant performs a deed in secret, so Allah writes it for him secretly. If he reveals it, it is transferred from secrecy and written in openness. If he speaks about it, it is transferred from secrecy and openness and written as ostentation (Riya).' And in the famous hadith: 'Seven whom Allah will shade on a day when there is no shade except His shade: one of them is a man who gives charity (Sadaqah) such that his left hand does not know what his right hand has given.' And in the report: 'Charity (Sadaqah) in secret extinguishes the wrath of the Lord.' And Allah the Exalted said: 'And if you conceal them and give them to the poor, it is better for you.' And the benefit of concealment is deliverance from the afflictions of ostentation (Riya) and reputation-seeking (Sum'ah), for the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: 'Allah does not accept from one who makes heard, nor from one who shows off, nor from one who reminds of his favor, and the one who speaks about his charity (Sadaqah) seeks reputation (Sum'ah), and the giver in a gathering of people aims for ostentation (Riya), and concealment and silence are the deliverance from it.'

The Fourth Duty: To make it apparent where he knows that in its manifestation there is encouragement for people to emulate, and to guard his secret from the incitement of showing off (Riya') through the method we will mention in treating showing off (Riya') in the Book of Showing Off (Riya'), for Allah the Exalted has said: 'If you disclose your charitable expenditures, they are good; but if you conceal them and give them to the poor, it is better for you, and He will remove from you some of your misdeeds. And Allah, of what you do, is Aware.' {} And that is where the situation necessitates the disclosure either for emulation or because the asker indeed asked in public, so it is not appropriate to abandon giving charity out of fear of showing off (Riya') in the manifestation, but rather one should give charity and guard his secret from showing off (Riya') as much as possible. And this is because in the manifestation there is a third danger besides reminding of favor (Mann) and showing off (Riya'), which is exposing the covering of the poor person, for perhaps he is harmed by being seen in the image of the needy, so whoever makes the asking apparent is the one who exposed his own covering, so one should not be cautious of this meaning in his manifestation, and it is like exposing immorality (Fisq) upon one who concealed it, for it is prohibited, and spying in it and habitual mention of it is forbidden. As for whoever exposes it, the establishment of the punishment upon him is publicizing, but he is the cause in it. And with a similar meaning, he said: 'Whoever throws off the cloak of modesty (Haya'), then there is no backbiting for him.' And Allah the Exalted has said: 'And spend from what We have provided for you secretly and publicly.' {} He encouraged to public also because of the benefit of encouragement in it, so let the servant (Abd) be precise in contemplation in weighing this benefit with the danger that is in it, for that differs with circumstances and persons. Indeed, the announcement in some circumstances for some persons may be better, and whoever knows the benefits and the dangers and does not look with the eye of desire, the most appropriate and fitting for every situation becomes clear to him.

Know that in secrecy for deeds there is the benefit of sincerity (Ikhlas) and salvation from ostentation (Riya), and in public display there is the benefit of emulation and encouraging people toward good, but in it there is the affliction of ostentation. Al-Hasan said: The Muslims have known that secrecy is more secure for the two deeds, but in public display there is also benefit, and therefore Allah the Exalted praised both secrecy and openness, saying: "If you manifest the charities, then how excellent they are; and if you conceal them and give them to the poor, then it is better for you." And public display is of two types: "one" is in the deed itself, "and the other" is speaking about what was done. The first type: manifesting the deed itself, like charity in public to encourage people in it, as narrated regarding the Ansari who came with a purse, so people followed in giving when they saw him, and the Prophet (peace be upon him) said: "Whoever establishes a good practice and acts upon it will have its reward and the reward of those who follow him," and all other deeds follow this course, such as prayer (Salah), fasting (Siyam), pilgrimage (Hajj), fighting (Ghazw), and others, but emulation in charity is more prevalent in dispositions.

Indeed, He, the Exalted, says: "The ignorant one deems them wealthy because of their self-restraint [al-ta'affuf]." As for the reports praising poverty [faqr], they are too numerous to count: 'Abdullah ibn 'Umar, may God be pleased with them both, narrated: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, said to his companions: "Who are the best of people?" They said: "A wealthy man of property who gives God's due from himself and his wealth." He said: "This is a good man, but he is not it." They said: "Then who are the best of people, O Messenger of God?" He said: "A poor man [faqir] who gives his utmost effort." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said to Bilal: "Meet God in a state of poverty [faqir], and do not meet Him in a state of wealth [ghani]." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Indeed, God loves the poor man [faqir] who is self-restrained [muta'affif], the father of dependents." And in the famous report: "The poor [fuqara'] of my community will enter Paradise [al-Jannah] before their wealthy [aghniya'] by five hundred years." And in another narration: "By forty autumns," meaning forty years. So the intended meaning is estimating the precedence of the poor man who is eager [haris] over the wealthy man who is eager [haris], and the estimation of five hundred years is the estimation of the poor man who is an ascetic [zahid] over the wealthy man who is desirous [raghib]. And what we have mentioned of the differing degrees of poverty [faqr] necessarily makes known to you the disparity among the poor [fuqara'] in their degrees. It is as if the poor man who is eager [haris] is at a degree of twenty-five degrees from the poor man who is an ascetic [zahid], for this is the proportion of forty to five hundred. And do not suppose that the estimation of the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, proceeds from his tongue arbitrarily or by coincidence. Rather, he, peace and blessings be upon him, is not made to speak except with the truth of reality [haqiqat al-haqq], for he does not speak from whim; it is not except a revelation revealed.

Indeed, the third category are those who restrict themselves to performing the obligatory duty [wajib], neither increasing upon it nor decreasing from it, and this is the lowest of the ranks. All of the common folk [al-'awamm] have restricted themselves to it due to their stinginess [bukhul] with wealth, their inclination towards it, and the weakness of their love for the Hereafter [al-akhira]. Allah, the Exalted, says: "If He were to ask you for it and press you, you would withhold and He would expose your resentment." (Qur'an 47:37) "Press you" [yuhfikum] means He would demand it from you exhaustively. So what a difference between a servant [abd] who has sold his wealth and his soul for the Garden [al-janna] that is for him, and a servant from whom it is not exhaustively demanded due to his stinginess! This is one of the meanings of Allah's command, glorified is He, to His servants to expend their wealth. The second meaning is purification [tathir] from the attribute of stinginess [bukhul], for it is among the destructive traits [al-muhlikat]. The Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Three things are destructive: obeyed greed [shuhh], a followed desire [hawa], and a man's admiration of himself." And the Exalted says: "And whoever is protected from the greed [shuhh] of his soul [nafs] â€“ it is those who will be the successful." (Qur'an 59:9) The aspect of it being destructive and the method of cleansing from it will come in the Book of Destructive Traits. The attribute of stinginess only departs by accustoming oneself to expending wealth, for love of a thing is not severed except by compelling the soul [nafs] to part from it until that becomes a habit [i'tiyad]. Thus, the alms [zakah] by this meaning is a purification [tuhrah]; meaning, it purifies its possessor from the foulness of destructive stinginess. Its purification is only according to the measure of his expenditure and according to the measure of his joy [farah] in giving it out and his gladness [istibshar] in spending it for the sake of Allah, the Exalted. The third meaning is gratitude [shukr] for the blessing [ni'mah]. For Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, has a blessing upon His servant in his self [nafs] and in his wealth. The bodily acts of worship [al-'ibadat al-badaniyyah] are gratitude for the blessing of the body, and the financial acts of worship [al-maliyyah] are gratitude for the blessing of wealth. ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
So what deluded you about Allah after you heard and understood? "They said: If we had listened or understood, we would not have been among the companions of the Blazing Fire. So they confessed their sin, and away with the companions of the Blazing Fire." If you say: Then where is the place of hope and its praiseworthy position? Know that it is praiseworthy in two situations: The first: Regarding the immersed sinner when repentance occurs to him, and Satan says to him: How will your repentance be accepted? So he despairs of the mercy of Allah the Exalted. "At this point, he must suppress despair with hope and remember 'Indeed, Allah forgives all sins' and that Allah is generous in accepting repentance from His servants, and that repentance is an obedience that expiates sins. Allah the Exalted said: 'Say: O My servants who have transgressed against themselves, do not despair of the mercy of Allah. Indeed, Allah forgives all sins. Indeed, He is the Forgiving, the Merciful. And turn to your Lord' - He commanded them to turn back. And He said: 'And indeed, I am Forgiving to whoever repents and believes and does righteous deeds and then remains guided.' So if he expects forgiveness with repentance, he is hopeful; but if he expects forgiveness with persistence in sin, he is deluded. Just as one for whom the time of Friday prayer becomes tight while he is in the market, and it occurs to him to hasten to the Friday prayer, and Satan says to him: You will not catch the Friday prayer, so stay in your place. So he rejects Satan and goes running while hoping to catch the Friday prayer - he is hopeful; but if he continues with trade and takes to hoping to catch the Friday prayer while staying put, he is deluded. The second: Regarding the righteous worker if he fears that his deed will not be accepted from him or that he will be sealed with evil. He must suppress fear with hope and remember His saying the Exalted: 'And fear a Day when you will be returned to Allah. Then every Soul (Nafs) will be compensated for what it earned, and they will not be wronged.' For He the Exalted promised that no one will be wronged. And He, the Exalted, said: 'On the day when Allah will resurrect them all together, then He will inform them of what they did. Allah has kept account of it, while they forgot it; and Allah is Witness over all things.' And He, the Exalted, said: 'On that day, the people will proceed in separate groups to be shown their deeds. So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it, and whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it.' And He, the Exalted, said: 'Then every Soul (Nafs) will be fully compensated for what it earned, and they will not be wronged.' And He, the Exalted, said: 'On the day when every Soul (Nafs) will find what it did of good presented, and what it did of evil, it will wish that between it and that [evil] was a great distance. And Allah warns you of Himself.' And He, the Exalted, said: 'And know that Allah knows what is in your Souls (Anfus), so beware of Him.' Then the possessors of insight (Arbab al-Basa'ir) from among the servants recognized that Allah, the Exalted, is lying in wait for them, and that they will be scrutinized in the account and demanded with the weight of an atom from the passing thoughts (Khatarat) and glances (Lahazat). And they realized that nothing will save them from these dangers except adhering to self-accounting (Muhasabah) and sincerity in self-observation (Muraqabah), and demanding from the Soul (Nafs) in breaths (Anfas) and movements (Harakat), and accounting it for passing thoughts (Khatarat) and glances (Lahazat).

a.g: O you who have believed, when you contract a debt for a specified term, write it down. And let a scribe write [it] between you in justice. Let no scribe refuse to write as Allah has taught him. So let him write and let the one who has the obligation dictate. And let him fear Allah, his Lord, and not leave anything out of it. But if the one who has the obligation is of limited understanding or weak or unable to dictate himself, then let his guardian dictate in justice. And bring to witness two witnesses from among your men. And if there are not two men [available], then a man and two women from those whom you accept as witnesses - so that if one of the women errs, then the other can remind her. And let not the witnesses refuse when they are called upon. And do not be [too] weary to write it, whether it is small or large, for its [specified] term. That is more just in the sight of Allah and stronger as evidence and more likely to prevent doubt between you, except when it is an immediate transaction which you conduct among yourselves. For [then] there is no blame upon you if you do not write it. And take witnesses when you conclude a contract. Let no scribe be harmed or any witness. For if you do so, indeed, it is [grave] disobedience in you. And fear Allah. And Allah teaches you. And Allah is Knowing of all things.

As for passing thoughts (Khawatir) and the inner speech (Hadith al-Nafs) and the agitation of desire, all of that does not enter under choice, so holding accountable for it is imposing what cannot be borne. Therefore, when His saying, the Exalted, descended: 'And if you disclose what is in your souls (Anfusikum) or conceal it, Allah will hold you accountable for it,' some people from the Companions came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and said: 'We have been imposed with what we cannot bear; indeed, one of us speaks to his soul (Nafs) with what he does not like to settle in his heart (Qalb), then he is held accountable for that.' He, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Perhaps you say as the Jews said: We hear and disobey; say: We hear and obey.' So they said: 'We hear and obey.' Then Allah sent down the relief after a year with His saying: 'Allah does not burden a soul (Nafs) except with what it can bear.' Thus, it became clear that everything from the actions of the heart (Qalb) that does not enter under capacity is what one is not held accountable for. This is the unveiling of the cover from this confusion.
