Know that this is an obscure matter, and there have come in it verses and reports that are contradictory, and the way to reconcile between them is unclear except to the brokers of the scholars of the Sharia. It has been narrated from the Prophet (peace be upon him) that he said: 'My community is forgiven for what their souls (Nafs) speak to them, as long as they do not speak it or act upon it.'[77] And Abu Hurairah said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: 'Indeed, Allah the Exalted says to the recording angels: If My servant intends a bad deed, do not write it down; if he acts upon it, write it down as one bad deed. And if he intends a good deed but does not act upon it, write it down as one good deed; if he acts upon it, write it down as ten.'[78] And it has been extracted by Al-Bukhari and Muslim in the two Sahihs, and it is evidence for forgiveness for the action of the heart (Qalb) and its intention for bad deeds. And in another wording: 'Whoever intends a good deed but does not act upon it, it is written for him as one good deed; and whoever intends a good deed and acts upon it, it is written for him up to seven hundredfold. And whoever intends a bad deed but does not act upon it, it is not written against him; and if he acts upon it, it is written.' And in another wording: 'And if he speaks of doing a bad deed, I forgive it for him as long as he does not act upon it.' And all of that indicates forgiveness. As for what indicates accountability, it is His saying, the Exalted: 'If you disclose what is in your souls (Nafs) or conceal it, Allah will hold you accountable for it, then He forgives whom He wills and punishes whom He wills.' And His saying, the Exalted: 'And do not pursue that of which you have no knowledge. Indeed, the hearing, the sight, and the heart (Fu'ad) - all of those will be questioned.' So it indicates that the action of the heart (Fu'ad) is like the action of hearing and sight, so it is not forgiven. And His saying, the Exalted: 'And do not conceal testimony, and whoever conceals it, then indeed his heart (Qalb) is sinful.' And His saying, the Exalted: 'Allah does not hold you accountable for the inadvertent in your oaths, but He holds you accountable for what your hearts (Qalb) have earned.' And the truth in our view on this matter cannot be determined unless there is comprehension of the details of the actions of the hearts (Qalb) from the beginning of their appearance until the action appears on the limbs. So we say: The first thing that comes to the heart (Qalb) is the thought (Khater), as if it occurs to him, for example, the image of a woman and that she is behind his back on the road, if he turned to her he would see her. The second is the agitation of desire to look, which is the movement of appetite in the nature (Tab'), and this is generated from the first thought, and we call it the inclination of the nature (Tab'), and the first is called the speech of the soul (Nafs). The third is the judgment of the heart (Qalb) that this should be done, meaning it should be looked at, for if the nature (Tab') inclines, the determination (Himmah) and intention (Niyyah) do not arise unless the deterrents are removed, for it may prevent him due to shame or fear from turning, and the absence of these deterrents may be due to contemplation, and it is in any case a judgment from the side of the intellect (Aql), and this is called belief (I'tiqad), and it follows the thought and inclination. The fourth is the firm resolve (Azm) to turn and the decisiveness of intention (Niyyah) in it, and this we call...

Indeed, for this reason, when the verse descended: "And whether you show what is within yourselves or conceal it, Allah will bring you to account for it," some people from the Companions came to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and said, "We have been tasked with what we cannot bear. Indeed, one of us converses with his soul [nafs] about what he would not love to become established in his heart [qalb], and then he is held accountable." It has been narrated that Iblis appeared to a monk, and the monk said to him, "Which of the character traits of the children of Adam is most helpful to you?" He said, "Hot-temperedness [al-hiddah], for when a servant is hot-tempered, we turn him over as children turn over a ball." And it is said that the Devil says, "How can the son of Adam overcome me? When he is pleased, I come until I am in his heart [qalb], and when he is angry, I fly until I am in his head." And from his great gates are envy [al-hasad] and greed [al-hirs]. So whenever a servant is greedy for everything, his greed blinds him and deafens him, as He, peace and blessings be upon him, said, "Your love for a thing blinds and deafens." And the light [nur] of insight [al-basirah] is what recognizes the entrances of the Devil. So when the covering [ghita'] of envy [al-hasad] and greed [al-hirs] is present, he does not see. Then, at that time, the Devil finds an opportunity and makes everything that leads the greedy one to his desire appear good to him, even if it is reprehensible and obscene.

And when Sufyan said that, he was asked: 'So what should we say?' He said: 'Say: "We believe in Allah and what has been revealed to us." And what difference is there between saying "We believe in Allah and what has been revealed to us" and saying "I am a believer"?' And it was said to Al-Hasan: 'Are you a believer?' He said: 'If Allah wills.' It was said to him: 'Why do you make an exception, O Abu Sa'id, in faith?' He said: 'I fear that if I say yes, Allah the Exalted would say: "You have lied, O Hasan," and the word would be established against me.' And he used to say: 'What assures me that Allah the Exalted has not looked upon me in some matter He dislikes and despised me and said: "Go away, I have not accepted your deeds," so I am working in vain?' And Ibrahim bin Adham said: 'If you are asked: "Are you a believer?" say: "There is no god but Allah."' And he said once: 'Say: "I do not doubt in faith, and your asking me is an innovation."' And it was said to 'Alqamah: 'Are you a believer?' He said: 'I hope, if Allah wills.' And Ath-Thawri said: 'We are believers in Allah, His angels, His books, and His messengers, and we do not know what we are with Allah the Exalted.' So what is the meaning of these exceptions? The answer is that this exception is correct and has four aspects: two aspects based on doubt, not in the origin of faith but in its conclusion or perfection, and two aspects not based on doubt. The first aspect: which does not rely on opposing doubt, is caution from certainty out of fear of what it contains of self-praise. Allah the Exalted said: 'So do not claim purity for yourselves' {} and said: 'Have you not seen those who claim purity for themselves?' {} and said: 'Look how they invent lies against Allah' {} and it was said to a wise man: 'What is ugly truth?' He said: 'A person's praise of himself, and faith is among the highest attributes of glory, and certainty is absolute self-praise, and the form of exception is like a weight for one who knows self-praise, as when it is said to a person: "Are you a doctor or jurist or exegete?" and he says: "Yes, if Allah wills," not in the context of doubt but to remove himself from praising himself, so the form is the form of hesitation and weakening of the news itself, and its meaning is the weakening necessary from the requisites of the news, which is self-praise, and with this interpretation, if asked about a blameworthy description, exception would not be proper. The second aspect: Adhering to etiquette by mentioning Allah the Exalted in every state and referring all matters to the will of Allah the Exalted, for Allah the Exalted taught His Prophet ï·º etiquette, so He said: 'And do not say'

The Fifth Principle: That it is permissible for Allah (Glory be to Him) to impose upon the creation what they cannot bear, contrary to the Mu'tazilites.
